38945125.review:
All wound up after a long day at work? Play Gorn. Best stress relief. Ever.

Extreme violence against nameless cartoony goons. Controls are smooth, making every parry, evisceration, smash, and physics-defying homerun smash extremely gratifying. The immersion will have you sweating after 15 minutes--either from fear of death, or the thrill of defeating those punks who spew nonsense words at you.

Replayability is pretty good for a VR title: plenty of weapon unlocks (*and now some hand modifications like a grapple chain and a steel fist), many ways to learn to use said weapons and the devs release new content often. Free Lives' passion is in this, and you can tell.

I can't give enough praise for Gorn. I practically bought a Vive for this title only and have no regrets. If you own VR and can take the violence (there's a toggle to turn off the gore if you'd prefer), you're missing out if you do not have this in your library.

**edit: Be careful of nearby meat-world objects. I've nicked the controllers at least twice now. Controller protection is advised.

38902468.review:
[h1]Gladiator Troncha-Mandos Simulator[/h1]
Es muy facil y muy rapido definir este juego:
Divertido, sencillo, original, sangriento (opcional) y muy adictivo. Una experiencia VR imprescindible.

Paso directamente a lo mejor y lo peor, que se que es lo que quereis ;):

[h1]PROS:[/h1]
-Graficos muy caricaturescos que funcionan muy bien. Tanto para enemigos como para las armas que son exageradamente grandes.
-Nivel de sangre configurable. Existe un "modo piñata" apto para todos los publicos.
-Con la sangre habilitada, desmembramientos y decapitaciones super divertidas.
-Desbloqueos de armas.
-Bosses.
-Modo infinito.
-Actualizaciones frecuentes. Fixes y de contenido.

[h1]CONS:[/h1]
-Pocas opciones de locomoción. El modo estandar de avanzar como remando me parece horrible. La locomoción libre solo permite el giro brusco o el giro "real". No existe modo de girar suave con los sticks y me parece un fallo.
-Me gustaria que hubiera mas variedad de enemigos. Son clones. Se lo perdono porque el juego es muy bueno, pero con enemigos más variados seria espectacular.
-Me gustaría que la sangre pareciera mas real.
-Si juegas mucho destruirás tus mandos, tu casa y herirás a tu familia y seres queridos.

En resumen, una experiencia VR muy divertida y muy recomendable que querrás mostrar a tus visitas.

Por si os sirve de ayuda, os dejo un video mostrando un poco el juego. Espero que os guste.

38896858.review: GORN is the first Vive native VR game to really do melee combat right. If any of you have played Robo Recall for the Rift then you know pretty much how the melee combat works in this game. What sets GORN's combat apart from Robo Recall is that there is no warp mechanic. Instead you "walk" by holding down the touch pad and swinging your arms. The walking mechanic felt awkward at first, but after a little while it started to feel surprisingly natural. In fact, I found myself wanting to swinging my arms to walk in other games I played. Grabbing items and enemies works as exactly as you'd expect. And the stretch 'wobbly' physics allow you to get very creative with how you dispatch each foe. GORN is a serious contender for best VR game of 2017 and a serious workout to boot!

38875710.review:
Honestly, I was expecting to refund this title. On the store page it looks like it's a simple game where you just wave fight mindless enemies with a bunch of weapons that are given to you. Seemed.... too simple. I was very wrong about this assumption.

Gorn doesn't explain all that well that there is actual progression and challenges/achievements to get these new weapons.

For instance, about every 5-6 fights you can fight a champion. There are 8 based on the wall I can see and they are unique enemies where you are given a certain set of weapons to deal with them. This actually makes me want to do some normal rounds to be able to beat all of the champions. Once you beat the champion you get a new weapon that that specific champion unlocks for you. Such as iron fists or a grapple gun fist.

A good example of a champion is Achilles. He is a fully armored enemy except for his ankle and you are given a sword, which performs very poorly against armor. So you end up having to parry his sword attacks which will slow-mo for a bit, then duck and swipe at his foot to kill him. It was a pretty enjoyable experience! I'm not going to lie.

There are also weapon challenges to get new weapons. For instance, there are 5 heart removals required with a Rapier  or Spear (also unlocked weapons, I don't remember how) that will unlock nun-chucks for you. Heart removals can only happen if you stab them in the chest around where the heart is. This makes each wave interesting since you have certain challenges you can focus on against these enemies. In other words, there are objectives each wave for the most part.

I have almost 2 hours in the game and have killed 5 champions. The combat is pretty satisfying since each weapon for the most part handles differently so you can find your favorite weapons of destruction. I personally like the axe the most and after that these metal fists they just introduced since you can block with your hands and then punch them to death while breaking their armor with your iron fists. It makes me feel super BA and like a super buff monster dude just like the guys I'm beating up.

One of the things I think VR is for is to make you feel like a superhero or something better than just a regular person. Gorn achieves this. If you are careless you can get killed, but the game isn't so hard that you feel it's impossible.

I'm also very glad that it has a strict chaperone that pauses the game if you get out of your chaperone area at all. It is super helpful since sometimes in frantic battles you really are swinging very hard or punching very hard to be fast to smack the enemy in time. I have about 8-12 inches of give past my chaperone to actual objects/walls and I haven't broke anything yet.

TLDR: The game actually has progression, achievements and lots of weapons. This makes it fun for me and makes me want to kill more champions/enemies to be able to unlock everything the game has to offer!

38794958.review:
Well, I personally believe that is one of the most addicting and fun wave-esk games out there. I always seems to come back to this game a get lost in it for hours it seems. 

It is both cartoony and gory, but makes you feel like you really are the gladiator. I believe there is movement options to change the smooth locomotion in the settings, but it is not as bad as some other games tend to be.

My current playspace is 2.1m x 1.6m (which is under recommended) ad the game is playable, but you definitely need to be careful with this one. You can get so into it that you hit your surroundings. There is an option called strict chaperone, whic pauses the game when you leave the bounds (or get to close), I would recommend turning this on. Your controllers, and surround furniture will thank you!

I can wholeheartedly reccommend this game to anyone.

38790441.review:
Gorn is a battle gladiaor simulator. It contains many types of weapons and powers. It may not look like a whole lot from the trailer or from gamplay, but it really never feels old. There is always something to do within the custom mode, boss mode, endless mode, party mode, or normal arena mode. With each weapon, it is a different experience. You have to stratagise around depending on what weapon you have. If you don't like to see all the bood and gore, you can turn your enemies into walking pinatas spilling out candy, which makes you feel far less insane. You can also give the middle finger...cause that's a thing.

This isn't a perfect game though... yet. It is still in early access, so it isn't completely a finished product yet. From playing this game on the oculus rift, I have encountered a few audio problems. At first the game didn't even have sound at all. I googled up how to fix it, and sure enough there was an answer. I went into my windows settings and disabled all of the other audio devices except the rift headphones. After I was finished with that game session, I re-enabled all of the devices except for the steam streaming mic and the steam streaming audio and the audio continued to work. Recently, when I was about to be killed by enemies in-game, my audio would temperarily cut out for a few seconds to almost a minute. I am not sure if this is because of a recent update that cuts out your hearing at near-death, or if this is just a bug. Either way, I don't really like it.

But overall, this is a pretty good game. It is actually one of my favorite VR experiences so far that I have played. Sure, the devs need to work on it some and add a little more content, but this is a [b]fun[/b] game. And after all, that is the whole point of video games, isn't it? At the current state, I give this game an 8/10.

PS. The amount of hours that it says reviewers have played may be too low if they use an Oculus Rift. (Like Myself) When the game is launched from Oculus home, (Which I normally do) it doesn't track the amount of time played on steam. In other words, I have a lot more hours on this game than it says I do.

38609897.review: Out of all the VR games I have in my collection, I feel like this is the game I always come back to. There's nothing more satisfying than literally ripping your enemies to shreds. The movement style took some getting used to but once you get the hang of it, it's pretty entertaining and even a slight workout. The weapons each have a different feel to them, some of them are buggy but that makes it even more hilarious at times. My personal favorite has to be the bow! Also, the development team is very friendly and open to feedback in the discussions here on steam and they have continued to update the game with new features and weapons as the community grows. 38515145.review:
Note: HIGHLY RECOMMEND wearing the wrist straps for your Vive controllers to avoid accidentally tossing your Vive controllers, and paying EXTRA attention to your room boundaries. Use the quick turn option in the game movement settings to cut down on bumping your room walls - made a big difference when I made that switch.

Legs, arms, feat, hands and head can be severed. Enemy armor can be destroyed piece by piece. Enemies with severed limbs will eventually bleed out and die on the spot. Cuts and severed limbs will spurt blood as well. You can chop heads at different angles revealing different parts of the skull/jaw. Weaker bladed strikes to the face will pop out an eye, or both eyeballs, or just leave a nasty cut on the face. Wounds reflect the type of attack (pierce vs slash vs bludgeon, single blade vs multiple blades, etc.)

You can parry enemy strikes. You can fight with a two-handed weapon, dual one-handers, bow and arrows, one-hander and shield, two shields, one shield and unarmed, or fully unarmed. You can grab enemies with one hand and smash their face in with your free hand You can grab an enemy and use them as a shield, or bludgeon another enemy to death with their body, or simply grab an enemy and smash his body against the ground until he dies. Hearts can be ripped out with piercing weapons (spear and rapier at least), heads can be ripped off as well.

Enemies often mistakenly hit their friends when swinging which is hilarious at times.

Default movement is a sort of arm pumping/skiing movement, but you can change this to a less involved option in-game to suit your playstyle.

Different weapons are unlocked based on certain achievement requirements involving boss battles and arena victories. Weapon challenges provide timed scenarios where you try to sever the most number of limbs, or smash the most amount of armor in a certain time limit.

My personal favorite is going Musashi with two one-handed swords in the decapitation challenge. Highly recommend you use the default Gorn movement. It's fantastic to get on a roll going berserk, chopping heads and pumping your arms like you're running through blood, limbs and heads in battle.

If you love violence as much as I do, you'll love Gorn. My current favorite VR game hands down.

38342951.review:
Epic amounts of brutal, bone-splintering, brain-pulversizing fun. The recent updates have improved an already fun game immeasurably. Let me break down the positives.

GRAPHICS: Fun, cartoony, consistant with the weapon design and immersive.

PHYSICS: By far, the draw cards of the game. Incredibly satisfying to smash, stab, swing and throw your weapons and see them have the desired (and undesired effects on your combatants)

WEAPONS: A wide range of killing instuments to allow you to adapt your play style. Become a Juggernaut swinging a huge morning star, or a lithe quick fencer stealing in for chest stabs to take as many hearts as possible. Awesome.

LOCOMOTION: Some options for this, but the recommended arm swing is by far the best. Takes some getting used to, but once you're there, it really (weirdly) helps with immersion (and calorie count). The winged gloves recently added allow you to leap into and out of action like a crazy flying...ninja... of um....gory.... death (running out of adjectives).

SUGGESTIONS: Very excited to see where this game goes. Already in an AWESOME place. Some humble thoughts. Would be good to have a wider variety of enemies (sizes, shapes, speeds, health, tactics). Would be great to have more content, more things to kill, weapons to get, skills to master, places to explore, more more more. To have the weapon's mastery system give you added benefits, an RPG lite feature kinda thing. 

Otherwise, some of the most fun I have had with my Vive. Made me proud to be a Saffer.

38342576.review:
Excellent. The movement options alone make this game worth the purchase. It's clear a lot of love has gone into this game. GORN is an exercise in creative approaches to locomotion in a literal proving ground where you engage in brutal combat with a whole catalog of martial (or feral) weapons. What more is there to say? Plenty!

Pros: 
 - Several movement styles to learn, each with strengths in the arena. 
 - Sometimes frantic, sometimes epic, always fun. Leap 20 feet in the air and let an arrow fly. Pretty satisfying.
 - Weapons combine in different ways to provide interesting gameplay challenges. Game progression encourages novelty, and one can choose custom battles/challenges with a weapon of your choice.
 - Several gameplay modes and enemy types. 
 - Controls feel tight and responsive. GORN gameplay is unique and the locomotion style is unlike anything I've played (standard locomotion is available).
 - Very good exercise.
 - Strict chaperone option pauses the game when I approach the edge of playspace. Given adequate room scale space, it is possible to play this game safely without punching things.
 - Lots of replayability.
 - The game interface is one of my favorite parts. GORN puts you in character, and the interface is the game. This is how VR content should be made. Nice job devs!
 - Non-violent mode makes me feel like less of a psychopath (this may be a con in the long run idk)
 - More customization options than I have yet explored. Tinker with scale, enemy strength, and more.

Areas for growth / questions:
 - Sore muscles for days and days. How can I stop being such a feeble-bodied peasant? 
 - Will you start looking at network features? I know PVP probably won't happen (and rightly so) but friends scores for challenges, PVE coop, some type of record/sharing option for a session -- any of those possible?
 - Will there be an option to change audio? I don't love the laugh track being on all the time.
 - Any plans to add new/different arenas? Perhaps a king-of-the-hill style map with different geometry?

TL;DR: Addictively fun arena game with a beautiful art style, combat in GORN feels feature complete (with obvious paths for growth, like more bosses, etc.). The flying fists of fury update is amazing, and really opens up the door to new playstyles. Thanks devs for the cool product!

38340973.review:
Sheesh, where do I even start a review on this?

When you haven't played it, or seen someone play it (or even if you have seen it), it doesn't look like a whole lot. Fight some guys, spray some blood, maybe slice off an arm or two, get beaned in the noggin and pass the Vive to Jeff.

Ho ho ho, no no no. I don't know what it is about this game, but there is [i]always[/i] something to do. There's always a new way to fight, a new way to approach the battle, and a new experience to be had. Yeah, it's a single arena and you fight an (unending, if you want) army of identical muscle-bound gladiators who constantly smile like they're strangely aroused and talk smack while a giant metal fist is hurdling at their squishy, unprotected flesh. You know what they say about judging a book by it's cover-- I guess that doesn't really apply here because it's not a book and doesn't really have a cover but you get the jist. If it was a book, the words on the pages would change every time you read it, and still be equally as exciting.

At nearly 60 hours and climbing almost every day, GORN holds the majority of my time spent in SteamVR. Other titles just haven't held my interest-- they got stale after I've done everything or the parts I liked were patched out (looking at you, Sairento). 60 hours in, playing in chunks of 10 minutes to 3 hours, I'm still not bored. It's still fun. It's still exhilarating, and it's still the best workout regimen I know of when I play it like I'm really there. Added on is the fact that it supports local multiplayer, either by the new party mode (introduced with the most recent update, this review written 12/15/17), or by hot-dropping into an in-progress game by just pressing start on a controller. I tend to prefer the latter because it allows you to play multiplayer in custom mode, which is unlocked by completing a set of tasks that I forget the exact details of. 

Party mode, however, allows multiple controller-players (I think? At least one.) who take control of an enemy gladiator who participates in the bloody free-for-all until the HMD player is elimitated, while racking up kills to grow stronger. I tend to work with the extra player to prolong the game as long as we can, and then switch.

Regular "old school" drop-in (pre-party mode update) is a little different in that you can plop yourself into a game at any time and take control over a previously AI controlled gladiator, and you switch between gladitors that are already fighting when you die, as opposed to spawning as a new one as you would in Party Mode. However, in regular drop-in mode, kills are not counted and you don't get yoked for getting more. There have been times where I've booted up SteamVR and set the headset on my bed just to play as one of the mortals by myself and still had a blast.

There are a plethora of weapons to use, each with its own unique abilities and drawbacks. As of the most recent update, there are a set of caestus-- special gloves that you equip in the lobby after you've unlocked them-- that extend your death-bringing abilities to a fantasy level that brings even more fun to the game with a seemingly unlimited combination of new ways to murder swaths of dim-witted meat puppets. You can have extendable claws, yank people across the arena with a chain, and even leap through the sky to descend upon your enemies in a superhuman fashion, plunging your arsenal of floppy poking tools into them and popping their limbs and bodies like sausage-filled balloons.

The game's primary developer, Ruan (apologies if primary developer is a misnomer in this case, but he seems to do the main mechanical work) hangs out in Discord on a regular basis and is open to feedback, suggestions and bug reports on a daily basis. I have personally seen bugs that I've reported fixed within a few hours while playing on the Experimental branch. The team that created this masterpiece as a whole seems very receptive to the community and supports what we want as much as they can. If you have any interest in VR melee combat, do not hesitate to pay full price for this game and support the development team as they deserve it and more.

GORN is, without a doubt, the most uniquely satisfying and most replayable VR game I own or have experienced. I haven't played a AAA VR game (as if there are many) that can even hold a candle to the intense, heart-racing and often hilarious antics that this game can provide. If there was an "Absolutely" button next to "Yes" I'd have pressed that.

38267590.review:
Do you have a room-scale VR setup and some aggression to take out on cartoon meatheads who skipped leg day? This is the game for you. Overall this game is really satisfying and a good way to blow off some steam and get your heart pumping. The combat can get so immersive you (sometimes disasterously) forget there's a real room around you. 

PROS
- Combat physics are cartoony, but feel solid and fun.
- This game is a good workout routine.
- You can give a people the bird.
- Locomotion is handled well with different options.
- Fun variety in ways to kill. Any limb can be chopped off, hearts come out, etc.
- Tons of modifiers, endless mode, and different weapon combos to keep replayability high.

CONS
- Enemys are REALLY dumb. They knock themselves out constantly.
- Badgers are annoying AF and they don't die or despawn. You have to knock them out of the arena. 
- The helium laughing (audience) gets really old after a while. 

Disclaimer: Wear your wrist straps and turn on that chaperone. You WILL break something.

The damage system is a bit annoying when going for harder unlocks, such as 10 kills with rocks, 1 hit and you are dead, unless you can get a kill before fade to black. + Any kills you got towards that unlock are lost if you die.

You quickly get a sense for what every weapon is good for, and how to defeat an armoured enemy, but the game never gets super-easy.

Bear in mind, however, a few things: odds are, the first time you play, you'll have some sore muscles. This didn't last, in my case, but it's worth knowing. Next, consider the space in your room. 38068854.review:
没有有价值的中文评测吗？那我来写一个。
买到VR之后第一时间浏览了推荐的VR游戏，这是我第一个看上的动作类。原因很简单，就是想运动和游戏两不误。
首先这个游戏没有中文，但其实也不那么重要，因为它根本没有剧情。一些设置查查字典就好，你需要做的就是杀爆竞技场上的所有人！！
移动是按住圆盘时，手往你要走的反方向甩。扳机按住是抓物品或握拳。按一下圆盘上面的键是切换紧握物品和松手。
========================================
再说一下武器的使用（惯用右手）。
利刃撕裂肉体，钝器有效破甲，非柔性近战武器可以防御近战，盾牌可以防御远程和近战。
西洋剑和矛：右脚在前左脚在后与敌人一条线，前者右手握住活动把控制矛头，左手握住固定把置于腰处，后者右手持剑，左手持盾或其他武器防御，攻击时跨步向前同时（双）手向前刺中敌人心脏或头。
连枷：右手举起，快速逆时针甩动，朝左下方攻击敌人。
弓箭和飞刀：为了方便，建议用圆盘上面的键保持持握。弓箭是左手持弓与两肩一条线，右手持箭拉弓并记住你手掌靠胸口的位置，左脚不动转动身体和上下摆动左手来控制准星。飞刀是右脚在前左脚在后与右手和敌人在一个面，右手举起，往下甩的同时放开扳机以甩出飞刀。两者可以回收。
巨锤：双手合并举起向前砸向敌人，或者横向扫击敌人；若敌人靠近，可以像长矛那样冲撞敌人。
双手连枷：因为这个游戏的武器都非常软，所以我还没弄明白如何使用。问题在于棍子部分软，而锤头重，像巨锤那样双手握一端的话棍子会弯曲。当我甩棍子的时候，锤头又不会根据惯性甩出去。我看专精试炼里说要把敌人甩出去？欢迎各位来探讨。
双节棍：感觉毫无实用性，钝器砸不烂铠甲，对肉体攻击也不强。
蛋刀：这玩意在现实中是不存在的，我用不起来，更加无法学习如何使用，姑且当单手剑用吧。
石头：没错，地板上的石头是可以作为武器的，不过也就和拳头一样的伤害而已。用它杀敌是一个成就哦！
========================================
再说说如何攻击敌人（惯用右手）：
武器实用性最高的是斧头和钉锤，最好左手持斧右手握锤。这样一来，双手都具有攻击和防御，且斧头对肉体，钉锤破甲。缺点就是无法防御远程武器。若敌人有弓或飞刀，建议左手换盾。
攻击主要以钉锤敲击敌人头部为主，若敌人持盾，可跳起进攻其头部或斧横砍其无铠甲的腿部。
如果你随机到的武器没有斧头和钉锤，斧头可以用剑替代，钉锤可以用锤子替代。其次建议使用巨锤，一砸一个。再次用弓箭远程杀敌后拿其武器，爆头一箭，戴头盔的两箭。

37851968.review:
Ignore the time played, I spent hours with this game at a friends house.

Interesting combat. Was initially going to return, but a friend convinced me to give the game a second chance, since I hadn't unlocked everything yet. There's a decent amount of content in the game, and the developers seem really willing to add things to the game, with updates being a fairly reliable source of new content in addition to fixing bugs. 

- Combat -
Something to keep in mind with this game is that while the melee combat isn't perfect (flailing your arms wildly can win most fights quickly), it still provides a good amount of variety with the way the different weapons handle. The flail surprised me with how well it functioned, and the spear and two-handed weapons caught me off guard with the way they handle (spears still flop around a bit too much for my liking though). The hammers are a bit OP, as either version of it breaks armor and seems to deal a lot of damage. Bows and throwing knives have accurate tracking, but have extremely limited ammo, making them less fun since you quickly have to ditch them to stay alive. You can pluck your ammo out of foes to reuse it, but it's kind of hard since enemies are like ragdolls that can lurch at you suddenly.

Remember Skyward Sword? The Nintendo game with Link and the annoying Siri thing? This game does it better. When you swing a weapon at a foe with armor, it doesn't deal damage until you break the armor off. Unrelated, but as seen in the trailers and comments, you can rip foes' appendages off. I learned the hard way you're not supposed to do this until there's like one foe left, as other enemies can and will ignore your morbid celebrations. You can use dead foes as human shields, which is something I did really like (especially against archers).

P.S. You parry enemies by attacking their weapon, regardless of whether the enemy is attacking or not. This is something I managed to exploit during multiple battles. 

- Health -
Since it never seems to be directly said in the game at any point, you do have an interesting health system. If you are hit by an enemy ONCE, your vision starts to fade and you will die within a few seconds. HOWEVER, you can immediately recover from this "dying" state by killing an enemy, encouraging you to go berserk in a last-ditch effort to stay alive. It's something that hasn't been seen in any VR games that I've played, and it reminds me of the Borderlands mechanic. 

- Replay Value -
This is the big hitter for me. I think I'd reccomend the game because of the updates, and since the latest one added MF Honey badgers, which adds a unique spin on combat (you can rip them off of your face and throw them at people) if they don't kill you in the first few seconds of their arrival in the arena. Local multiplayer is a big plus that kept me and my friends coming back to this game, kind of like Blue Effect but instead of scaring each other you just flail at each other until one person dies. It's kind of great. 

- Content -

You can unlock most of the game's content in about an hour, but most of the content is locked behind an achievement wall... by fulfilling challenges such as getting headshots with a bow or parrying enemy attacks, you can unlock additional starting weapons for your randomized starting lineup, along with boss battles and challenge modes, including an endless mode. As it stands, it's an okay game, but with a few extra updates, such as time of day/lighting differences, stage hazards like a pit of lava, or a bit of enemy body type variation, this game could quickly become something really impressive. 

- Verdict -
Try the game and play for about an hour, or try to conquer the first six bosses. At this point you'll have experienced most of what the game has to offer, and it should give you an idea of whether or not the game is worth keeping.

37692720.review:
This game is absolutely hilarious.  I bought this on a whim when it was on sale, since I'd been eyeing some of the boxing games for Oculus, and I was very pleasantly surprised.

As many here have already explained the mechanics, I won't - other than to say it's a gladitorial game.  Your in an arena, you pick weapons, you fight.  Simple.

However, despite how bland that might sound, the game just never gets old.  Every fight is a different mixture of opponents, some armored, some not; some armed, some not.  The over-the-top damage you do to your opponents is hilarious and gruesome at the same time - weapons do what you'd expect them to do.  Lop an arm or leg off with a sword.  Bash a helmeted head with a mace.  Run an opponent through with the spear or poinard.  The combat mechanics are very well done (for VR), and you can block attacks with every weapon instead of just using it to fight.  The sounds are excellent - the clang of weapons on armor, the horrible thunk of a warhammer on an unprotected skull, etc.

In addition, the game is a room-scale game, and you can build up quite a sweat from playing this game.  After about 30 minutes of playing it the first time I was breathing like I'd run a quarter mile.  With that said, make absolutely sure you have enough room to play this - as you WILL be flailing your arms around like a blind madman.  I hit the wall and nearly broke my monitor in the first 10 minutes (the video above is not that  much of an exaggeration).

I very heavily recommend this game to all VR gamers.  It's simply too much fun to not have in your library.

"Es qui Es!!"

Brutal, gory and extremly funny. These are just a few words to describe this game.

The Combat in this game is very satisfying as every hit feels brutal and the precision with which you can strike, stab and smash is amazing. Knocking enemie's weapons out of the way and going in for the killing blow, grab one by the throat and bash his face in with a hammer, stab somebody in the chest with a spear and then lift them up and throw them across the arena...there is sooo much funny things in this game.

Next to the normal arena mode with random weapons and enemies, there are also champion battles in which you have to defete a specific enemie with a predefined set of weapons.

All in all i had a tremendous time with this game and every once in a while i return to the arena to blow of some steam. It's just an very entertaining and funny game.

36847957.review:
Chcek out our Live Vive playthrough video here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JBXwO3N-jwQ&index=15&list=PLrByqnQJN7X9PRCuf06iyLa5ZSr5pd14B

Gorn is a gladiatorial combat in a full virtual reality setting. Developed by: Free Lives and Published by :Devolver digital this full room scaled gore fest puts you right in the action for each swing of the sword. Is it worth  Step into the collisium and face off against lowley scrubs to fully armored behemoths, using motion control to shoot, stab and bash each foe you face. Use the room scale features to dodge attacks and revel in the gore you spill with each strike. 

	The wepons in Gorn are what really sell the experience. From the bow and arrow piercing the armor of your enemy to the heavy 2 handed maul knocking them clear out of the arena almost every weapon you pick up feels real. Gone are the days of just waggling your hand to cause damage with motion controls, in Gorn the speed and placement of your swing determines the effectiveness of your attack. Quick stabbing motions with the small daggers can be just as effective as large lumbering swings with 2 handed mace. Knowing how to use each weapon is not only key to winning fights but also key to unlocking new and better weapons.

36814874.review: I'm gonna be honest: I'm worried about this game. People have said that games like Call of Duty or GTA could make kids violent, and we've already debunked that. But this game requires actual violence to play, and I can't say that I'm not loving every second of it. So you're thrust into this Roman collesseum-type area and forced to fight naked versions of the Heavy from TF2, and it all seems normal. But after five minutes of playing, you take of your sweat-soaked headset and realize that it's been hours and your house has been reduced to a pile of dust. The only thing I would change is the creepy faces of the dudes. I thought it was way less scary on itch.io. That being said I give this game an 8 out of 10 for being early access.

35716781.review:
GORN is a fantasticly brutal VR bash-em-up that, after only 2 hours of play, I can honestly say is one of the best VR games I've played.

I had my doubts about GORN. It looked fun, but swinging weapons and holding objects in VR that are supposed to be heavy hasn't been a huge hit for me in VR. Until now. With the first swing of the flail, I was hooked. Bashing ridiculously out of proportion Roman Gladiators' heads in gets more and more satisfying with every new arena venture. Slice, swing, bludgeon and bash your way through waves and waves of wobbly Gladiators. Throw your hands up in victory to the deafening shouts of your adoring disembodied, floating headed fans.

GORN also offers a couple of different locomotion options too. Akin to Climbey, the grip buttons are the classic locomotion and offer a similar type of movement to your top-heavy enemies. Trackpad locomotion is also an option, and it works perfeclty, but I feel GORN loses a little bit of it's magic if you aren't stumbling about like you just drank a flagon of ale. Just like your enemies.

In my opinion, GORN is a defining VR game. It takes a very simple and classic game concept, and adds Virtual Reality flair. Something we all enjoy, but with a VR twist. A must-own and an instant VR classic, in my eyes.

The gates seperate him from a gaggle of ornery men, some adorned with armor pieces and others wearing nothing but their underoos. The Great Head in the Sky commands a salute from his warriors and they comply. The gates lower and the carnage begins. The lone warrior slashes and bashes through countless enemies, blood his reward and sustained injury, his curse. A growl is heard from behind, and as he swirls around to face the next opponent, he spy's, not a man, but rather, a badger. The cute creature looks at the man and he returns the gaze in kind. The look is almost hopeful, if not comforting. The man drops his sword and shield and bends down to pick up the creature. The last thing heard from the ring that day was the bloodcurdling screeches of a man who could not find peace until the very bloody end.

+ Physics - everything has (rubber) physics, which basically means everything can be a weapon (even opponent's body parts)
+ It's just fun - even fighting alone is great fun, but there are also challenges, unlocking of new weapons and powerful champions
+ Local multiplayer - you can battle your friends on pc

- Might get repetitive after while - enemies have the same moves; if you learn how to dodge and counterattack, classic battle mode gets too easy - luckily there are challenges with weaker weapons which can be challenging against armored opponents

• You can play it even with smaller area than the store page says it requires - but there is higher chance of smashing controllers into something (and that is pretty high even with recommended playspace)
• Blood can be turned off - you can let kids play GORN in piñata mode

[b]Movement[/b]: 		Touchpad locomotion, Arm-swing (I don't recommend it if you don't suffer from motion sickness)
[b]Controls[/b]: 		Motion controllers + Gamepad (for local multiplayer)

[b]My progress[/b]: 		3 hours, defeated all champions
[b]Recommended price[/b]: 	15-20 €

[u]My overall recommendation score: [b]85%[/b][/u]

35194239.review:
Hands down my favorite VR game to date. Jump in for 5 mins, or just play is straight for a couple of hours - I just don't seem to get bored of this game. I have already unlocked all weapons, and reset the game - currently on my third run through. Its exhausting, but exhilarating. Beyond gory, but satisfying. The most satisfying fighting mechanics I have seem in a VR game to date.

My only (minor) complaints about this game:
The locomotion system did take a little time to get used to, It's really a limit of the technology though, not this game. Without magic transporting (which would not work in this game), moving more than 3 feet just isn't practical in VR today.

You do need more space than the average game to play - you will want at least a ft of space around your play area to make sure you aren't banging into walls - but it's well worth the extra space.

For the life of me I cannot figure out how you are supposed to correctly use most of the two handed weapons. The weight of the giant flail and the hammer is just wrong and makes them pretty pointless. That said, other weapons are perfect - give me the giant axe and the basic sword and I will fill your arena with bodies (and body parts) all day long.

Gorn is so fun it has ruined other fighting games for me!

35017739.review:
I think most of us are murderous animals inside, at least in part.  It's totally natural, and an okay thing to be.  Anyone with a hind-brain can probably relate.  The thing that's unnatural is the society we've built that depends on us NOT expressing that facet of our being - one that i believe we all share, though some of us are better at diverting or suppressing it than others.  

Gorn is the best, most immersive, most rewarding way to express that deep-seated, reptilian aggression without violating any of society's expectations.  I think that Gorn is the most honest video game i've ever played.  

It's completely replaced my (admittedly light) exercise routine.  i bought wrist weights so i could keep pushing myself physically.  I kill over a hundred men a day, every day, and i cannot wait to exercise each evening.  I have never felt that way about working out in my life.  

Gorn is one of those pursuits where the more you put into it, the more you're gonna get out of it.  If you let yourself really enter the arena, let your living room melt away, really get your blood up - then i think you'll have a better time than if you try to play it in an "optimized" or physically lazy way.   Don't play this game with your wrists, play it with your shoulders.  

While the game is designed to be a sort of testosterone-fuelled gratification of an adolescent power fantasy, the women in my life who've tried it report satisfaction too, often more emphatically than the dudes.   The person i've seen enjoy it the most is a 5'2" canadian library sciences student.  She's a fucking maniac in there, man.  

I've had to replace both controllers that came with my vive because of this game.  I nearly destroyed a 4k television playing the itch.io version.  there's a high likelihood that the gouges i've left in my living room wall will need to be repaired out of my security deposit.  They might need to get a contractor in here.  So far this game has cost me about $300 in property damage, we'll see how that number rises when i move out of this apartment.  

Gorn is costly, violent and physcially taxing.  and i could not recommend it more highly.

35012757.review:
TLDR: One of the BEST VR GAMES.  Dont think twice.  Buy it now.  BUY IT.  BUY BUY BUY BUY!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Holy crap, GORN is so much fun!  I was having a shitty day, my morning mocha was undrinkably shitty because some shithead trainee doesn't know how to make coffee, and i was out of good coffee at the apartment, and the kitchen is a god damn mess and my servants never clean up when they're supposed to, and I could just go on for hours... so I was mad and decided to blow off steam by hopping on Steam VR.  Incidentally, I think that could be a clever marketing thing.  "Blow off some steam with Steam... VR!" I think of brilliant things like this all the time but it's like nobody ever reads the comments I leave on Reddit.).  I digress. 

I spent most of the afternoon beating the shit out of people until I accidentally raised my hand into the ceiling fan and almost broke my thumb.  I have decided that if I'm ever thrust into gladiatorial combat there are two weapons I should never try to use: flails and swords.  Now, you can't kill yourself in GORN - at least not that I've seen - but I can certainly tell when I *ought* to have been dead because of an errant thrust or swing.  The flail may be my favorite weapon in the game, but if I'm being honest, I ought to have bashed my own brains in more than a few times.  The sword, by contrast, appears to me to be the most difficult weapon to use in the game, which tells me it is probably exponentially more difficult to use in real life.

However, after GORN I'm expertly prepared to face real life gladiatorial combat.  I know exactly which kinds of weapons to choose, when given the choice: caveman weapons.  Anyone can swing a club.  I can usually swing a club and not kill myself in the process.  Hammers, clubs, maces, baseball bats, whatever.  Anything more advanced takes greater and greater degrees of skill, until you get to crossbows and finally guns where you've gone back to caveman skill, but with the lethality of an Olympic God.

I mean, with a couple of decently skilled marksmen a gunfight comes downt o who can point at the other guy fastest.  It's a pretty funny way to duel each other, here in the future.  You used to have to get sweaty.  And brother, did I get sweaty playing GORN!  I had to take off my shirt, the sweat glistening down my long greasy hair.

I don't know why this review got weird, I'm sorry.  Bye.

34854635.review:
Alas, GORN, How I wanted to love thee!

The game had good and bad, but ultimately I ended up refunding it. I am clearly in the minority in my rating so bear in mind, this is just my personal opinion. If you're interested, buy it, test it for 1.9 hours and make up your mind. But I found the following with this game - 

The positive:
The movement in this game is original and causes no motion sickness at all. I mean really, it's slick.

A nice mix of weapons and challenges, some of which revolve around picking up dead foes weapons. So you actually have to think.

Damn good exercie. I was all sweaty and [strike]worn[/strike] GORN out. It was a good workout.

Some of the animations were funny the 1st few times.

You can actually give the finger lol.

The negative:
I know this is EA so it's difficult to complain but, really, after just under 2 hours I realized all this is, is repeatedly trying to melee the exact same, cartoony looking, 1-3 wobbly guys with bendy legs and weapons over, and over, and over. For all of that positive, I just got... bored. Hopelessly bored. 

After just 2 hours I had almost every weapon, and was working my way though the challenges (more or less). It's a fun game, really fun, at first. Most of the reviews (though not all) have less than 5-7 hours played, that's about how long this game is fun for in my opinion. 

It can be very frustrating, watch Jacksepticeye and how annoyed he gets at not being able to effectively parry certain hits because the weapons actually wobble. 

All in all, it is a fun game at first. Just don't expect a lot of mileage out of it. I refunded mine.

34783760.review:
Serious contender for both Best Game In History and Best Room Breaker of all Time.

I cannot remember when I last had this much fun in a simple game.  Everything about the game (room breaking aside) is absolutely perfect, right down to the comically floppy weapons (at times) and the insane physics issues that can occur at high speed.

I also don't remember the last time a game made me sweat this much, if ever!  The adrenaline rush and the general feel of the combat leave me hungry for more, even when my body can't take it.  I'm genuinely worried I'll hurt my vive by sweating on it too much, and thus it's time I cave and pick up a waterproof cover.

The only other thing I'd like to see would be a change in scenery, perhaps.  Give us a forest clearing, with guys popping out of the trees, or a crossroads surrounded by burning wagons to mask loading and spawning.  I don't so much care about the coins at the end or anything, so there's no reason that needs to be the only way to end a match.  Perhaps a bunch of leaves falling, or friendly soldiers of some kind showing up (introducing asymetrical co-op! - aside from the custom stuff we can do already).

Overall, I cannot recommend this game enough.  11/10, this one knocks it out of the park.  Literally! (I love you, 2H Hammer of overpowered insanity!)

34460866.review:
Highly enjoyable experience, and most of all true to the video. :) 

Video review can be seen here:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fcENYOfma-M

Mechanics:

The movement mechanics are unique.  You do have the option to change it to using the joystick, however I decided to give it a chance.  It took me a few matches, but I got the hang of it fairly quickly, think of it as cross-country skiing motions.   

Weapons:

Weapons are a lot of fun.  I enjoyed the challenge of using the bow…You only have a limited number of arrows.  After which you need to retrieve them from the corpses otherwise face your beatdown!  Some rubber banding effect with the bigger weapons, but it adds more comedic value than a serious bug mainly do to the overall theme and gameplay style.

Gameplay:

Pretty simple gameplay…Gladiator arena, where you face off with multiple (dumb) weapon wielding grunts.  One, two no problems, when there are many, all surrounding you, you need to start thinking a plan, otherwise nighty night!
When you are in the mood to beat up / maim this is a great game to jump in and play.  Just make sure you have enough space.  I already came close to busting one of my Oculus Touch controllers as when I was trying to hack a ‘grunt’ with my sword, I was a little too close to the wall.  😊  

Okay now for the negative:

It’s a simple game, repetitive in nature.  Hopefully there will be some new characters instead of the same old grunts.  Multiplayer could potentially add some unique challenges.  A campaign would be nice, start off as a nobody, and work you way up the chain to eventually get your freedom. 

Overall:

The game, as it’s still in Early Access is so far a lot of fun, even with its simplicity nature.  Price point is fair for what you are getting.  I’m generally not one to buy early access games, as I’ve seen many times developers just never complete them, however I am curious to where they plan to take this.

If you are looking for something fun I would recommend this game.  Also if you get the desire to watch ‘Gladiator’ no you are not crazy…I too had the same feeling after playing this for a couple of hours.

34387641.review:
GORN is one of the most enjoyable and exhausting games I've played on the Vive.

[h1]Weapons[/h1]
You get a nice array of weapons to play with from swords/axes/hammers to a brace of throwing daggers or a giant flail. My personal favorites are the spear for its lunge capability and the rapier/shield for stabbing at the enemy from cover. The variety in weapons actually feels like variety because they all play to various strengths and weaknesses.

[h1]Movement[/h1]
Movement was a bit of a chore at first using the default style of movement (clicking track pads and swinging arms) but once I switched to the scheme where you can just click-and-hold the pads in a direction to move things got a lot easier. If you have a setup like mine where the cord drops behind you to the floor you may have the same trouble I did with taking advantage of the 360 degree aspect of the game. I've been mainly working with about 300 degrees of rotation and I feel somewhat vulnerable as a result.

[h1]Combat[/h1]
The combat is gorey in a goofy way with limbs popping off, eyes hanging out of sockets, and being able to gore enemy hearts right out of their chest. You can even abandon conventional weapons and pull their head off orm bash it in with a rock.

[h1]Modes[/h1]
A standard campaign that gets harder with each fight won eventually unlocking the ability to fight unique champion enemies. Eventually you unlock an Endless mode. That's it, but it's more than enough and keeps the menus simple and the time outside of combat minimal.

What really makes this game worth the money to me is the workout it can provide. After so many fights you won't be able to raise your arms above your head (the move to signify you're ready for the battle to begin) and the sweat will be pooling in your eyes.

34185807.review:
Fantastic arena fighter with intuitive combat and stellar design!

Everything about this game oozes quality; from the physical feedback of cracking your opponent's skull with a heavy mace, to the clean slice of cleaving their arm with an iron blade. The sounds are satisfying, and are equally as gory as the visuals that accompany them. The game sets a new precedent for how combat works in video games. It's a huge milestone for gaming, and is above and beyond anything else that currently exists. 

It is well worth the $19.99 base price.

GORN raises the bar and sets a new standard for how melee combat should be from now on. Those AAA studios cannot help but be shamed in comparision to what this small team has accomplished.

My Rating: ★★★★☆ 4/5

I bought this, weighted straps for my waist, ankles, and wrists for some fun and extra exercise on my off gym days.  Two days later after hour long sessions, I will be giving up my gym time for this. This game should be mandatory for high schoolers who don't want to take gym class.

As a legit review though, this game is intense, strenuous, and kind of shallow.  There isn't a story (or not one that I have found yet) and while this game is the definition of repetitive it is always exciting and will always get your heart pumping.   Simply for the bloodlust and adrenaline you are guaranteed to get this deserves a 10/10, however I do have a few gripes.  I do not see anywhere on the page or requirements but you HAVE to have a 360 setup and you HAVE to have room (no standing in one spot) or you cannot play this game. I also kind of have an issue with how you turn, because you have to turn in real life you have to constantly be conscience of your cord which really does not let you full emerse yourself.  I feel like the developers should allow for turning via joystick to at least be an option until wireless VRs/VR attachments come out.

So if you have a 360 set up, don't mind sweating and potentially breaking something you need to buy this game.

34145977.review:
My initial review of this game was unfair and negatively rated the game on the fact it didn't support front facing setup, which upon reflection is like complaining that your vegan meal has no steak. The game has since been updated to support  front facing setup as well as accomodation for those with limited space through the implementation of in game turning via the analogue sticks (Rift). While I have a 360 setup and just enough space for room setup I play using a Standing Room steam setup to minimize punching my walls or windows out and the game works beautifully. 

The Dev also took the time to reply directly to my initial review stating that in game turning had been implemented after the recent update was released, that's pretty damn impressive not many would take the time to do that - push out an update then locate a review from weeks prior and reply to it. 

As a game it's pretty solid and enjoyable, loving the recent custom battles feature. As a HEMA practioner of over a decade it's enjoyable being able to parry then immediately deliver a riposte against the ai. Local multiplayer as well is something I would never have imagined but could also allow me to share the experience with my kids.

34075623.review:
I got the Oculus Rift and I bought this game on Launch and the controls were absolutely terrible.  You had to keep the grip trigger button down to keep holding the weapon and you could only move by clicking down on the thumbstick while also moving the controller in a "skiing motion."  They finally patched that up so you can keep holding the weapon with just a click and you can press "A" button and do the skiing motion and it's made moving around a whole lot easier.  

Game is fun.  You get a good workout.  Very gory.  Lots of weapons to try out.  A few different enemy types with varying levels of difficulty.  Of course, you can also do crude gestures and tear all types of body parts out.  Blood splatters all over.  This game is fun in spurts and a nice game to show off to friends how fun VR can be.  

However, this game also still has a few bugs.  Weapons still fly out of your hand for no apparent reason.  The best strategy is usually to either flail about your weapon or to move to a decent spot to hit your enemy first.  As far as I can tell, having a shield is not very strategic.  Spear is kinda OP.  Really, it's just about having a long reach and being able to hit your enemy before they can hit you and not getting ganked from behind (like prison!).   

So this game can get repetitive.  Definitely a close call but I recommend even at $19.99.  But you may want to wait for sale if anything about the above bothers you.  It's mindless fun.  Your mileage may vary.  

Rating: 7/10

34066220.review:
There are so many VR games out there that offer boring, unimmersive, cheaply implemented melee combat (e.g. you hit an enemy and it just doesn't feel as if an actual physical contact was made). Not this game. This game does it right. The combat feels very immersive and realistic. If you hit an enemy, the physical feedback is very accurate. If you slice an arm with your sword, you cut it right off where you hit it. The entire body of an enemy can be wounded and ripped apart in all places (again very realistically related to where and how you hit them). The weapons themselves are physically simulated as well and it feels as if you were acutally wielding them. Even two handed weapons can be used very naturally - you don't need any tutorial, because you just use them the way you would in real life (if you were a gladitor fighting for you life, hehe)

If this was an actual RPG it would be the best game ever :P

34005631.review:
TL;DR: Buy this game right now. You won't find better melee anywhere else in VR.

I've got to say, this game is already well-worth the money, and the dev isn't showing any signs of slowing down in content. This is gonna be a long one so buckle in, boys and girls.

Pros:

- Unbelievably good melee combat that is leagues beyond the competition. There's such a variety of weapons and they all shine in their own ways (some more than others, admittedly) You didn't know how impactful VR could feel until you've beaten a guy to death with a rock or swung a flail as it dynamically crushes your opponants armour.

- Plenty of content. The game has more of a "sandbox" feel to it than a campaign or anything. However, there is definitely already progression. You can unlock new weapons by defeating enemies in the arena (removing 5 hearts with a spear, for example) and you will also find your arena runs get progressively more challenging, unlocking bosses in a special "challenge" mode which is insanely fun.

- Just as fun to watch as it is to play. This game isn't for the faint of heart though. Be very selective who you give a go of this game, because you really want your "VR legs" and good spacial awareness, otherwise you'll smash everything around you, including yourself. The trailer speaks for itself and it's no joke.

- Incredibly immersive. At first you think "wow, these gladiators look kinda dumb" and similarly "what the hell are those big-headed dudes in the crowd?" but once you land your first punch, you'll be right at home. Enemies are dynamically injured, and their arnour is dynamically broken as well. You can remove limbs, tear off heads, impale hearts and shatter bones. Your enemies will still (try to) fight with those grusome wounds too.

- "Honest" combat. Enemy attacks are somewhat predetermined, meaning they will usually swing their weapon in a variety of general directions. The beauty is how many variables affect their swings to make them all behave very differently. Your first time going up against a guy with a flail is terrifying, until he manages to knock himself out with the flail swinging above his head, which happens rarely enough to be hilarious every time.

- Slow-mo. Let's face it, slow-mo combat always feels cool. So when you expertly parry their swing or land a headshot with an arrow, the triggered slow-mo not only feels great, but you can set up your next attack for some lethal combos.

- Weapon variety. I mentioned this earlier, but weapons aren't just aesthetically different. Some weapons, such as swords or axes, can decapitate foes with lethal efficiency, but struggle to penetrate plate. However, hammers and flails can crush that plate or leave foes stunned, leaving those fleshy bits exposed for the kill. Spears can accurately penetrate gaps in armour and bleed your enemies out slowly. Bows and throwing knives can disable your enemies and pick them off from a distance. Shields are invaluable for dealing wtih bowmen or protecting your flank. Rocks smash faces. There's still many more weapons beyond that, too.

- Multiple modes. Currently there is arena (typically for unlocking weapons, usually lasts a few waves), challenge (1v1 duels with some very intimidating bosses) and also endless mode (massacre as many people as possible and beat your high score) There are also many more modes currently being tested in experimental mode (which anyone can optionally access once they buy the game) but I'll just mention what's in the "official" version.

- Variety of movement types. There are currently technically 3 types of movement (2 really) in the game, walking with the touchpads (HMD or controller facing) and GORN. The latter is definitely the way the game is supposed to be played, and looks fantastic when people get the hang of it, but I personally use the latter HMD walking. I find the GORN movement to be very difficult to use but have no serious problems with my own familiar movement method, though your combat potential is definitely higher using GORN movement since you can dash in before they can react.

- Fantastic dev. This is probably the biggest positive to me. This dev is unbelievably responsive to the community. I have even spoke with Ruan a few times already regarding a few suggestions I had, and he took my feedback on board and had the one he liked on the "experimental" version within a couple of days! Somebody else, around the same time, said it would be cool to have an "invincible" mode where you can beat people up freely. "Sure, added" said the dev. Also on the experimental version already as I type this. In a world where the EA market is flooded with garbage and cash-grabs, this dev is like an oasis in the desert.

Cons:

- The game really needs space. I hinted to this earlier, but you will need roomscale for this game. You will sweat and you will ache. The game recommends 2x2 metres to play. I currently play around 2.2x1.6, so not ideal. That being said, if you regularly check you are central to your playspace, you should be fine with around 1.5x1.5 (but bigger is always better). If you have less than that, you'd better be damn good at staying in the centre or you (and anyone near you) are gonna have a bad time.

- Because of the last point and the sheer chaos the game can have going on sometimes, this game isn't something you'd give to someone who hasn't played VR before. If you want to risk it, make them wear the wristwraps and make sure they can hear you over the game volume (leave an earplug out or something) so you can guide them away from smashing your room apart when necessary.

- The game still needs optimisation, as with most early access games. I run the game with a pretty good GPU (RX 480) and the game does run at a very good framerate usually. However, there are times when the framerate can chug quite hard, particularly when there's a lot of ragdoll physics going on (hitting a bunch of dudes with a greathammer, shattering multiple pieces of armour and sending blood and people flying everywhere) although these have been few and far between for me. Certainly hasn't impeded my enjoyment of the game too much, but worth mentioning still.

- This game can be frustratingly hard or too easy sometimeas. Early on most people will probably find the game very easy, especially with cheese tactics, but difficulty can rise deceptively quickly once multiple enemies start showing up, especially when they wear armour. Sometimes you can feel like you just don't have the right weapons around to fight, as fighting an fully-armoured foes without a blunt weapon or an archer without a shield to block his arrows can feel like suicide. As you can only withstand two hits before you die (from any weapon, even fists) you really do have to be careful with the risks you take in combat.

- Some weapons currently don't feel as fun as they should. This is mainly personal preference here. The rapier feels like it needs more range to get effective stabs without the player being too exposed to counterattacks. the nun-chucks are awesome (because they're damn nun-chucks) but there's no real reason to use them over other weapons, as they aren't particularly effective at damaging armour or breaking bones, yet suffer from a very low range (though they attack very fast to possibly make up for that.) Throwing knives are bloody hard to use, they're extremely cool and satisfying when you land one but definitely take lots of practise if you want those glorious headshot kills.

- Glitchy (no way?!) Sometimes weapons feel kinda like they're inflatable (as they sometimes bend in weird ways to avoid clipping) but they feel too impactful and deadly to always feel like that. I personally find this compromise to be much better than magically clipping through everything constantly or the weapon "seperating" from you. Sometimes physics can "break" but usually the results are hilarious, not obnoxious.

Buy this game.

Your Inner Spartacus will thank you...in BLOOD!

33610038.review:
Playing on Oculus Touch, i5-7600K CPU with GTX 1070 GPU.

GORN isn't perfect, but it is the best representation of melee combat I've seen in VR so far.  Concept is pretty simple, they put you in an arena with CPU controlled fighters, give you a random selection of weapons to choose from, you salute the emperor (raise your hands) and then fight.  If you enjoyed Drunkn Bar Fight, this game does it MUCH better.

Default locomotion is done by clicking in the thumbsticks and "pulling" yourself across the ground.  There have been a lot of complaints about this movement style, so they have recently added free thumbstick locomotion.  I honestly prefer the default, classic GORN style of movement because it allows much faster and more agile movement, but to each his own.

Fighting is simple and intuitive.  Blunt objects stun enemies when hitting them on the head, and break armor quickly.  Slashing weapons (sword, axe) will sever unarmored limbs.  Stabby weapons (spear, dagger) will stun or insta-kill when stabbing someone in the chest or face.  Giant weapons require two hands but can knock people around the ring, easily break armor, and can stun regardless of armor.  But you already know this because that's what all these weapons would probably do in real life as well.

Starting out, your choice of weapons is slim.  Unlocking new weapons is done through fulfilling objectives.  For example, killing 5 people with the mace unlocks a weapon, killing 5 people with that weapon unlocks another weapon, etc.  Some weapons are only unlocked by picking them off of a dead body and killing five people with that weapon (e.g. Sword is unlocked this way).  Eventually you will have a variety of weapons to choose from at the beginning of every fight, although that variety is random every time.  Sometimes you may not get your favorite weapon and have to make do with the choices you have.  This isn't particularly a bad thing, since sometimes you find out new ways to utilize a weapon you originally hated.  I hated the nunchucks at first, but after being forced to use them a few times, I found out they're exceptionally good for stunning enemies.

After playing the normal game mode for a while, you unlock "champion battle", which is basically boss fights.  Currently there are only a few boss fights available, but once you finish them all, there is a sign on the door saying "More coming soon" (or something along those lines) so hopefully they add more of those because they were interesting.  One of the bosses even has a special move where he jumps at you through the air, wielding a two-handed warhammer.  I am really looking forward to more little AI routines like this one to spice up combat.

I will admit that at first, I felt cautious about paying $15 for GORN.  At a glance it seems like there isn't much there, and that's not really an inaccurate observation.  What IS there is what matters though, the game is extremely fun to play even in its current state and that should be what matters most.  If you're looking for anything resembling a story or deep character progression, you may want to wait before buying this.  If you're looking for a fun VR game that currently represents the feeling of melee combat better than any game I have ever played, then I'd recommend picking this up.

33604349.review: Destroyed my PC and Oculus Rift while playing this game..

33604202.review:
Genjales Spiel!

Gorn ist eines der Games, warum man sich ein VR System kauft:
Man bewegt sich, man schlägt, man dreht und duckt sich! Und das ganze macht ein riesen Spass!

Das Game ist definitiv nichts für Kinder, das nicht nur das Blut in Strömen fliesst, sondern auch Organe (Herz) herausgerissen, Schädel gespalten und Körperteile abgetrennt werden können. Sogar das abreissen der Körperteile ist möglich. Für Erwachsene bietet das Spiel aber immer mal wieder ein Gelächter, wenn man einen Gladiator packt und dann gegen die anderen Gegner schleudert oder man mit ihnen "den Boden aufnimmt" ^^

Das Handling fühlt sich intuitiv an, einzige Ausnahme bildet hier die Fortbewegung - die aber nach ein paar sekunden auch felsenfest sitzt und sich dann sogar recht witzig und passend anfühlt.

Ziel ist es, in der Arena vor Caesar gegen eine Menge Gladiatoren zu kämpfen.
Nach ein paar Runden in der Arena kann man dann jeweils gegen einen Gegner antreten. Diese haben immer spezielle Schwachpunkte oder man muss sie speziell angehen. Zum Beispiel Achilles den man hald an einem bestimmten Punkt an seinem Körper treffen muss - was ich ehrlichgesagt mega witzig fand. Oder Goliat der komplett Gepanzert daher kommt.

Kleine Erfolge sind ebenfalls mitdrin: Zwischen 5 und 10 tötungen mit einer Speziellen Waffe - die man getöteten Gegner abnehmen kann - schaltet man die entsprechende Waffe frei und kann sie ab dann in der zum Start vorliegenden Waffenkammer selber auswählen.


Negativ aufgefallen ist eigentlich nicht wirklich was, man kassiert immer mal wieder einen Treffer ob wohl man geblockt hat, oder Gegner treffen einen einfach gar nicht. Aber diese Punkte sind nicht speziell erwähnenswert, denn selbst wenn man selber zu Muus verarbeitet worden ist: Man ist so schnell wieder im Spiel - das dies definitiv zu vernachlässigen ist.


Zusammengefasst:
Mit Gorn erhaltet ihr ein Spiel das dich innert 10 - 15 Minuten klatsch nass macht weil du so schwitzt. Man kann richtig die Luft raus lassen, wenn man zu viel energie hat und es macht einfach unheimlich Spass, alles im Weg wegzukloppen.
Die seltenen geblockten Treffer die trotzdem durchkommen sind nicht wirklich schlimm, da man sofort wieder in einem neuen Game ist, und weiterkloppen kann. Ein einfaches Spiel mit viel Humor das einem echt auspowern kann.

10 von 10 Pixeln für ein VR Game.
So muss das!

33596923.review:
This is what VR was made for.  I've been playing this since I downloaded the alpha prototype demo elsewhere some time ago and just had to buy the full game as soon as it came on steam.

If you've ever fantasized about decapitating heads and spearing a gladiator in the chest and ripping his heart out, this is for you. If you've ever wanted to shout ARE YOU NOT ENTERTAINED to the crowds and give them the middle finger, this is also for you.

GORN is the most mindless murderfest I've ever played.

Built from the ground up for VR you can see how much attention the developers have put into this to make the physics feel like real combat physics. And the results speak for themselves. In this GORN you can't just wrist flick your fake VR sword quickly left and right to score hits like in other games, rather you have to swing each hit into position with force and precision.

The weapons feel just right, you swing a flail around in circles like you would in real life to get the momentum going then clobber some dude in the head and watch it explode. Eyeballs pop out, heads get sliced in half, this is brutal combat but in a ridiculously cartoony fashion. The spear actually feels like it has a long reach and you have strategically aim for his exposed chest or head depend which body part you feel like ripping off. If you got the sword and a shielded gladiator dude comes up, you can literally duck his attack and slice his legs in half.  Sword and shields combat has never felt so real.

This game is a must for VR,  but make sure you have lots of space in your room because i've had quite a few close hits with my TV etc. Also, this game is one hell of a sweaty workout I'd hate to think how knackered real gladiators got. 

Definite positive, there's no other sword combat simulator that offers such an immersive physical experience.

33570068.review:
(For full disclosure I was given a Beta key, and I've been playing it since version 0.3 [I think] on itch.io)

GORN is easily one of the best VR experiences out there. If you ever want to host a VR party, start up GORN, give the person playing [i]plenty[/i] of space, and enjoy the show.

You would think combat in VR would feel floaty and unsatisfying, and while that can be the case, the way GORN handles the combat with everything being physics based animated ragdolls, it never feels like you're just hitting air; it just makes you feel like you're powerful enough to swat away your opponents with ease.

If you have a VR headset of any kind, you owe it to yourself to pick this up.

(Reviewed on Oculus + Touch)

33567597.review:
[h1]Gorn - [i]The arena fighting game we have always wanted but never knew it![/i][/h1]
So ever since I brought Gorn on a passionate recommendation from a colleague of mine I have been somewhat addicted and since I stream and it is not uncommon for me to commentate while streaming “I just pulled his leg off and beat him to death with it” my neighbours have been crossing the street to avoid me. 
Now it is worth remembering what the term Gorn means, it is an amalgamation of Gore and porn, blood for the sake of blood, violence for violence sake, this is NOT a game for kids, given its VR and you are actually pulling off people's heads and bashing out brains with rocks,  I really should not have to state that but we live in an age where parents think “hey it’s a game, must be kid friendly” ….no do not let little Timmy play this :) 
Ok so you are an adult, you know the difference between reality and games? Good then look, you can read the rest of the review, I want you to, it took time to write after all, but you know what...just go buy the game, you will love it! 
I have always loved arena games from Shadow of Rome to the tiny arena mini-game in ps3’s move sports and when I first stepped into VR my initial thought was “This needs an arena game!” although there have been attempts at it this is the first one I have found hard to put down.
How hard to put down? Well in a live stream on Thursday I caught my knuckle on a table, blood everywhere (remember to clear your VR area folks) a few hours later despite not having full use of that finger I was back streaming for another 2-hour session. 
At the end of every game of it, I am drenched in sweat (and my “day” job means I am an active person no couch potato here) so it also doubles as a fitness game.

[b]ROOMSCALE / ENVIRONMENT / GRAPHICS[/b]
 The arena is a fair size and you have to love the giant heads watching you lol, the actual art style is leaning towards cartoony, teamfortress 2 like (again not for kids) with some really well-done gore effects (they are deeply impressive) 
The weapons have some bizarre qualities (almost rubbery at times, until you use them) which adds to the game, it is amusing to hold a spear one handed and seeing it flop limp like a flaccid ...well ok you can see where that analogy is going ;) (remember this game is not for kids ...neither is this review) 
While some would argue that they may wish to see new arenas, personally I feel the one we have is perfect for this game.


[b]PERFORMANCE[/b] 
[strike]I have had moments where the physics have wigged out and things have flown strangely or stretched out, mostly this is a cause of amusement (though often resulting in your in-game death) but on rare occasions, it has caused the frame rate or game to freeze for a few seconds. This, however, is rare and the game recovers beautifully from it.
The only other issue is that in the latest build I lost the ability to loose arrows, instead, they drop to the floor, an issue I hope the developer notes and fixes soon (is reported)[/strike]
***UPDATE 25/10/17*** Performance is near perfect now and the bow issue is fixed

[b]INTUITIVENESS[/b] 
You beat them to death before they beat you to death….I mean it is fairly intuitive.
The one downside is that whenever you load it your movement is defaulted to arm swing motion (a god awful movement system where you hold the touchpad and swing your arm to move) and you have to make your way to the options board to set it to the better touchpad locomotion (The dev clearly loves arm swing motion and it did take persuading for us to get an option added). 

[b]PROS:[/b] 
[list]
[*] Very addictive
[*] You can tear off a man’s arm and beat him to death with it.
[*] you can kneel down and stick a finger up at an enemy that has no arms, one leg and its rolling towards you with menace. (yep Monty python jumps to my mind to, Tis but a flesh wound)
[*] A good sense of progression, unlocking new weapons by using the others a certain amount of times, enemies get harder and you unlock bosses.
[*] A developer that listens to his users (so long as you are not asking for new movement...though even there he did listen after a while) and adds things in like demo mode so your mates can try the game without having to face the waves of now peeved, leveled enemies who are waiting for you to log back in so they can have a quiet word about how you pulled their mate George’s head off and bashed in Fred's skull with it.
[*] An endless mode that is a see how long you can last type deal where the enemies get steadily better equipped (best mode in the game in my opinion)
[*] Strange and challenging Boss fights (with the tease that more will be added)
[*] You WILL get a good workout if played properly.
[*] I guarantee there will at least one moment where you pull off something so amazing that you will wish you were recording 
[*] More than fair price.
[*] ***UPDATE 25/10/17*** rabid badgers....one of the bosses has rabid badgers
[/list]

[b]CONS:[/b] 
[list]
[*] [strike]The bow bug, it is really annoying and the developer seems to be ignoring it or not responding on topics about it. [/strike]***UPDATE 25/10/17 this is not an issue anymore***
[*] The endless mode has to be unlocked and yet is the most fun mode.***UPDATE 25/10/17*** When additional bosses are added you lose access to endless mode, endless mode, endless mode remains my favourite mode and it was frustrating to find it locked out.
[*] [strike]Certain weapons like the throwing knives(awesome weapon) do not appear in Endless mode[/strike] ***UPDATE 25/10/17 They do now so ignore this***
[*] If you are not physically fit or not into getting a workout this may not be for you.
[*] Can get VERY hard.
[*] Explaining to a mate on the phone how you threw the throwing knife into one guy's head while bashing the skull in of a guy with a mace still clutched in the hands of his friends severed arm, will get you strange looks from other people on the bus no matter how quiet you talk….I dread to think what government watch lists I may be on due to my gaming habits. 
[/list]

[b]VIDEO:[/b]
This is one of those games where video does not do it justice, that said here is a tiny clip (you can find full videos of it on my twitch channel, should you wish to)

https://clips.twitch.tv/OutstandingAbstruseMushroom4Head


[b]VERDICT[/b] 

Own VR? Over 18? Buy Gorn.
I really love the game and can not recommend it highly enough.
***Update 25/10/17*** Do I still recommend it all this time later? hell yeah I do, why do you not have it yet?

had gorn for 2 days now and heres how those 2 days have gone:

Day 1: Booted up the game excited for my first taste of a gladiator type vr experience. Day2: After the intense combat of day 1 i felt like i had been hit by a train, but the arena called to me. 33548799.review:
Definitely the best arena simulator I've ever played for VR.  I've played it since its early alpha days (it was available for free on their website), and it has come a long way even from the last free build.  The biggest improvements for me are that you can now walk around the arena (the free version had no VR movement system) and we now get to choose our weapons from a selection of five of our unlocked weapons, rather than being given two random weapons.  Overall, it's good, gruesome fun, with a pretty reasonable balance between weapon types.

Having said all that - if you come from a fighting background and expect a super realistic fighting simulator, this might be the best VR has to offer, but it's still not what you're looking for.  In particular, blocking is done pretty poorly - it seems you have to block the damage-dealing part of your enemy's weapon with the damage-dealing part of your weapon, so those of us who have been trained to stop the arm swinging that weapon instead might need to adjust their tactics.

33513202.review:
I've been playing since an early release on itch.io, and I must say this game has always been great, but it just keeps getting better and better.  Some pros and cons.

Pros: 
1. Great graphics style.  It's not too intensive on your system, and seeing the bones and blood doesn't make you cringe in disgust.

2. Big variety of weapons.  From swords to a giant hammer for destroying armor, you can be guaranteed to find a good weapon to fit you.

3. Super satisfying to kill and cut off limbs of your enemies.

4. Dev is a great person and is always listening for ways to enhance the game, and knows what's good and what's not good for the game.

5.  3 different game modes to pick from, and all are very fun.

Cons:

1. Some small bugs like enemies glitching around the map and somehow hitting you.  (While very funny, it is still a bug)

2. Movement system doesn't fit all people.  Many people are used to teleportation, which this game does not have.  I'm perfectly fine with the movement systems currently in place, but some people get extremely motion sick.  Sadly, I believe teleportation would ruin the toughness of the game.

Pulled the arrow out of his face, shot his friend next to him in the face, pulled that arrow out and got punched by a buff guy, so I tossed down the bow and ripped his head off.  With a bloody head in hand, I threw it to another new buff guy who showed up and stunned him, giving me enough time to pick up my trusty bow and blood arrow and launch 2 arrows into head stunned guy's chest.
