33488085.review:
I've played most of the melee combat VR games available and GORN stands well above the others for one reason: physics-based combat. Instead of memorizing attack animations and learning when to swing where as you will in numerous other games, GORN will have you actually parry, move, and strike in a very natural way.

The realistic nature of a physics-based combat system contrasts starkly with the humorous style the game presents through the condescending caricatures of onlookers above the arena, the wobbly movements of your enemies, the rubbery flexible nature of the shafts of all the weapons, and the wonderful showers of blood and gore the game offers. The result is a masterpiece that takes the right things seriously, and makes light of all the rest.

I strongly recommend this game to anyone who has sufficient space to play it. There are some caveats though -- first off, it is worth reiterating you NEED proper space to play this game. If you have a crowded VR space with lots of fragile objects, children/pets who may enter your gaming area while you are playing, or an aversion to sweating profusely, this game may not be ideal for you. Be aware that no matter how effectively you've managed to avoid hitting things while playing other games, GORN has a strong potential to change that. The trailer is not a joke.

Two interesting design choices that stood out to me in this game that I think are worth addressing beyond the physics-based combat are movement and the flexible weapon shafts.
[list]
[*] Movement
GORN uses an arm-swinging movement mechanic that will leave you feeling far less fast and mobile than most other melee combat VR games. You will rely on your roomscale space more than you do in other games as a result of this, so make sure you have plenty of space. This also makes it feel like you really need to fight to survive, running is not a very viable strategy.

[*] Flexible weapon shafts
A problem that plagues all VR melee combat games is the cheesy "wiggling" tactics to kill enemies. If you've played a lot of the other offerings out there, you have almost certainly encountered this. GORN solves this problem completely with the rubbery weapon shafts as damage seems to be based on the momentum of the weapon when it hits the enemy. If you wiggle the weapon around without committing to a proper swing, it is not going to kill anything.
[/list]

33473943.review:
EDIT: Review updated and stance change for a more full view of the game.

GORN is a fun romp through cartoonishly over-the-top violence and GORE.

Soem of GORN's biggest strength lie in its simplicity. You jus tbeat stuff up. It's too satisfyin to rip an opponent's arms off or stab their literal heart out of their chest.

An array of unlockable weapons and unique Champion fights keep things fun and exhilarating.

The combat is straight forward, grab a weapon and go. You unlock new weapons as you do specific actions within the arena mode, which ramp up in difficulty as you progress.

There is 1 major problem at the time of writing that still plagues this game, locomotion.

Movement in this game is controlled by holding down the tocuhpad and esseintially pulling yourself across the field. This doesn't feel problematic at first with light armor enemies and decent enough weapons, but when the difficulty beings to raise, you're going to find yourself more and more frustrated with being unable to move.

This is certainly an early access game, and it has a lot of potential, but the Developer needs to come up with a new locomotion system, or change how enemies behave in accordance to that.

It's a fun game that I've ejoyed since alpha, but I hope the developer listens to consumer concerns and implements new movement options, and perhaps a sandbox mode to try the weapons against different opponents, or make your own fun matches.

33472734.review: Best VR game hands down. Have tons of hours in the free alpha between myself and demoing to my friends. When I demo, this is all they want to play. $20 ($14.99 right now) is a steal for such a fun game. Don't let the people who only played for 30 minutes tell you there's no replayability. This game is endless fun and will only improve if this dev keeps up his hard work. Thanks for this game.

33472478.review:
So I've done melee combat in VR before, but Gorn gets a lot of things right. It's not perfect, but it has potential to be a real contender for the standard in VR melee.

Gorn, as of the moment (Early Access), is an arena fighter where you're some Roman gladiator or some shit. Locomotion is kind of strange - you swing your arms while alternating touch pad presses, as if you were climbing a ladder on the ground (H3VR does something similar for the challenge course things it has). Either hand is open and closes with a trigger pull, or you can invert it with the menu button and open on click instead, which is useful for using weapons.

Hand to hand combat is the focus, and it's pretty good. The game utilizes physics to judge the strength of your attacks, so there's a different between jabs and swings, pokes and slams. I think it's better to list what you can do than just outline it.

You can:
[list][*]Punch
[*]Rip off heads and arms
[*]Swing or toss said parts
[*]Pick up and use bodies as shields, or throw them
[*]Swing swords and axes (chopping off parts or cutting heads in half)
[*]Smash armor and shields with hammers, morning stars and maces (armor flies off as if Guts™ smashed a dude)
[*]Use two handed weapons like war hammers, giant morning stars and spears (and puck out hearts with a poke)
[*]Attach throwing knives to one arm for quick distance attacks
[*]Use a bow and arrow
[*]Parry strikes with a weapon to slow time down
[*]Nunchaku bro
[*]Use a shield and bash someone's face in with it
[*]Flip off the emperor[/list]

Most weapons are things you have to unlock doing challenges, like killing with certain weapons or a particular way. Enemies are all the same aside from different armored bits and different weapons. Weapons determine how the enemies attack you, but they are all sort of dumb grunts that move in to strike you, which is fine for this game (though they will probably need harder enemies or a harder mode down the line). Enemies come in random waves ranging from 1 to 5 enemies at a time.

Some tips:
[list][*]Clear your space
[*]Don't let people new to VR play
[*]Use your wrist straps[/list]

33469908.review: GORN is a ton of fun, it has been out for about a year now. Over the year the developer has taken it from a third party download alpha state, to an early access steam release. You will sweat, smash your controller, face, and possessions; but you will smile while doing so. This game should probably be priced at half its current value given the barbones content. It has one map, one enemy type, and a movement system that is by far the worst in VR. The movement set up makes you move as sluggish as the enemys but results in excessive energy being burnt on your end making you sweat uncontrollably. The developer needs to add double the weapons, at least 3 more maps, more enemy types (not just different armors), and please a better ability to block. Overall it is a great deal of fun, but as is common with VR experiences, expensive for the current amount of content.

33469729.review:
This is a fantastic VR title. It should be an automatic pick up for anyone who has a VR system. It has some of the most satifying combat and damage properties of any game. Really helps complete the experience when you're able to actually see the damage an enemy is taking. Combat works exactly how you would thing it would. Block with your weapon smash/hit/slice off arms and the enemy loses the ability to use it. It's great fun.

Is it worth the asking price? Yes definately. But keep in mind as with all early access titles, it is somewhat light on content. But for an EA game, I feel that it has much more content then the vast majority of other VR titles.

33468834.review:
HeadSweat Simulator

A great game that will have you smashing all your belongings in no time. 

Having played a number of VR games since purchase, this is one of few that i've felt compelled to go back in and play the same day i purchased and played it. Having weapons slightly rubberized makes the combat actually feel good, you don't feel there is an issue with the contact of the weapons as they are not just stiff objects that are light as a feather. 

The games movement system needs slight tuning, increased speed or a remapping of buttons so its the trigger you use to grab and possibly increasing the distance you move slightly. (Fixed with Lomotion)  

The combat plays really well, the AI is stupid enough that you can actually make progress without flailing your arms. You can actually duel these characters to a certain extent but the AI isn't too dumb that its just an easy smash kill smash kill experience. Variety in weapons is nice but i would prefer there to be a definitive pick up button or an option to change. Having to press the menu button for toggle grab is great but it also makes picking things up in a hurry impossibly hard, the collision boxes for certain items should be larger to help the fluidity of the game(FIXED WITH LARGER HANDS) and there should be either grab and hold toggled or not toggled, no use of different buttons.

Despite the movement being slightly clunky and perhaps not as tuned as it should be its definitely not a deterrent as the size of the arena doesn't warrant free range quick movement. The combat is clunky enough to feel it has some skill gap to it but fine tuned enough so you feel you are at fault for your own deaths.

Overall a must have for VR players and a great sales pitch for Headset sweat covers and micro towels.

33466740.review:
Yeah, it's good. Amazing fun. Incredible mechanics and loads of ways to destroy your enemies.

But be warned, you will probably give your HTC Vive water damage from how much you sweat. And your arms swinging about? Damn. I wish the chaperone boundaries were on 24/7. 

The game is hard, though. Very hard.  Be careful when finishing the bosses because the regular arena turns into endless mode. Which is fucking stupid if you haven't unlocked all the weapons, as you aren't credited for the kills with specific weapons until the end. Furthermore; the enemies take several hits to break through including the armour which some weapons can barely punch through.

So who thought it was a good fucking idea to make you die in 2 hits I don't know, but you're an awful person. You can't even regenerate - You need to play so carefully and it goes from fun to incredibly frustrating.

Also, RNG for the weapon spawns at the beginning? Come on. I had to kill myself 5 times before the damn bow spawned, and then having to go through 4 waves of enemies and LIVE or your progress is reset? Boy, the game gets not fun. 

What I'd like to see: 
- No RNG on weapon spawns at the beginning. 
- Increased HP before dying (Or even a toggleable godmode)
- Better tracking of weapon unlocks.
- Regular arena not turning into endless mode.
- A new arena.

33460766.review:
(Free key obtained during closed Beta tests)

GORN is a wonderful VR melee combat game. Killing your enemies has never felt more physical in VR. A great way of letting off some steam, but be warned: the trailer is not just a joke! 

There's not much of a story but the insane amount of immersion and physicality totally make up for that. The game solves the issue of "waggling at the enemy" by having slightly jiggly weapons. This jiggle will seem strange at first but you'll warm up to it quickly! The game also features several wacky boss-fights which are one on one fights against fighters with distinct abilities. The game also features an endless mode to see how long you can last against an unending barrage of gladiators. 

The developers pushed updates very often to the "experimental" branch during development and I foresee no change in this behaviour, so this game being Early Access will pay off in the long run. 

Please give GORN a try, but be careful of your fingers, or worse: your controller!

33454425.review:
moritura te salutant!

Tu sei un gladiatore pronto a lottare nell'arena, per la tua vita e la gloria.
Gorn è un gioco divertente e appagante. Brandire le armi, rotearle sopra la testa per poi sferrare potenti colpi sugli avversari e sentire gli spettatori andare in delirio da una soddisfazione infinita! 

La grafica è accattivante, piacevolmente "cartoonesca" e smorza i toni dei combattimenti che sono molto splatter! 
Puoi interagire i diversi modi con i tuoi avversari, infatti i combattimenti non si riducono a semplici scontri all'arma bianca, puoi anche afferrarli, strattonarli o spingerli per destabilizzarli e/o colpirli. 

Potrai fracassare scudi, armature, il corpo dei tuoi avversari a colpi di mazza, o mozzare loro gli arti con la spada e anche fracassargli la faccia solo con i pugni!  
Man mano che andrai avanti nel gioco (in base ai tuoi risultati) sbloccherai nuove armi e riceverai degli inviti a partecipare a degli eventi speciali!

Inizialmente (poi mi sono abituato) non ho trovato comodissimo il sistema di locomozione, ogni volta che si desidera andare in una direzione devi premere il pad del controller e muovere il relativo braccio nella direzione opposta a quella in cui si vuole andare, a me da un po la sensazione di fare il tiro alla fune...

Il comparto audio sembra incompleto, mi spiego meglio: gli effetti sonori ci sono tutti ma alcuni sono palesemente provvisori mentre la musica è quasi del tutto assente (per ora) nel gioco.

Per chiudere, Gorn è un gioco da comprare se hai l'anima del gladiatore e se non temi l'idea di fare mooolto movimento!

P.s. il prezzo è giusto ci stà!

But this is definitely not for everyone.  Overall I just couldn't get over the feeling of how sloppy and unfinished everything felt to me, was not expecting that after hearing about this game for most of the past year.  The combat felt better than any other melee VR game due to great collisions and random attacks of enemies, but still not very engaging since usually you can just race up to someone and smash them in the head or take advantage of their stupidity otherwise.  An improvement over other melee games, but we still have a long way to go in this regard.the enemies movements almost felt too random and/or predictable and random... hard to explain..  Just was not fun to me.  Graphics are consistent and stylized but didn't keep my attention, the goofy animations are supposed to be funny and allow for the rediculous ragdoll but it didn't sit right with me, didn't hold my attention.  Sound seemed good, flailing a morningstar over my head was epic, but the flashes of fun will not be enough to keep me coming back to this one.  Unfortunately I could already tell I wouldn't load it up again after the half hour I played  =(

Sorry to give it a negative review, I know it's got a lot of hype right now, but I just didn't find it fun.  I'll probably give it another go when full release is done since it definitely has potential.

It's odd, off-putting and quite annoying. If you're gonna create a game about fighting & gore, you need to pump that hard-rock/metal. Get us fired up!

33449370.review:
Incredibly creative, gleeful ultraviolence. This game forces you to really use your space. If you find yourself overwhelmed by multiple opponents it can be best to dodge physically around them (if you have the room for it) and watch as their "allies" cut them to shreds. 

But, back to that ultraviolence. Want to punch a guy's face off? You can. Want to deftly pluck a guy's heart out with your spear, then flick it over to his buddy? You can. Want to kill a guy, then tear his head off and raise it above your head in tribute to the watching masses? You can. In the time I've spent with the game I feel like I've only scrated the surface of ridiculous combinations of mechanics, weapons, and enemy types. 

My only complaint is that the unlocks come a bit *too* fast. Since you can always scavenge any weapon on the battlefield, I think in the future it'd be nicer if you had to work a bit more to be able to always have your favourite weapon right at the start.

截至目前，这游戏有四宗最：最血腥暴力的VR游戏，最适合发泄的VR游戏，AI最傻却又最搞笑的VR游戏，打击感最好的冷兵器格斗VR游戏。

这游戏的免费版公测了很久，群众基础很好，很长一段时间我都是只闻其名，懒得去玩，因为看见那画面那人物就没兴趣了，直到玩过后才知道这游戏有多好，现在的Steam版比测试版好太多了，细节方面很多改进，绝对值得购买。

四肢发达、三寸金莲、头脑简单，这就是你要挑战的白痴对手，除了用冷兵器，你还可以赤手空拳，手撕肢解，鲜血直喷，还有内脏，随手举起对手也可以当做人肉盾牌或武器。一个正经的冷兵器格斗游戏，对手却那么傻，这种反差，非但不违和，也不影响打击感，还很搞笑，这是这游戏设计最巧妙的地方！

一双小脚的大块头，脚小无脑，走路一瘸一拐，偶尔还会摔倒，几个人一起边挥武器边走路时，还会打到自己人，傻得可爱，不要太搞笑。这个设计巧妙在，避免了物理效果失真时导致的出戏感（毕竟现阶段VR游戏的物理碰撞效果做得再好也不能跟现实比），碰到失真情况反而显得很搞笑。

一个冷兵器格斗VR游戏做得这么搞笑幽默，但最核心的打击感才是最牛逼的，每种武器的物理效果都是精心制作的，并不只是换个造型而已，兵器有很多，碰撞做得很好，灵敏度恰到好处。就连我快要射到麻木了的弓箭，在这游戏射箭爆头竟然是最爽的，还有长枪刺向对手爆头，每个武器都有个特别爽的地方！

最后，还是温馨提示：这是控制器杀手中的杀手！小心撞墙撞东西！

Who doesn't like to punch some faces, slice some arms off and shatter opponents armor with great feedback ? Room furnitures, if they are also shattered in the process.
Edit: I didn't watch the new trailer, it shows that. Great one.

Awesome game, but watch out.

Players need to carefully learn how to manage real space in VR world. I didn't try to turn chaperone always on, but I guess it helps to learn.
An usual strategy is to match a real world wall/corner to a virtual one, then coming back to a similar position after some virtual locomotion to kill an archer or whatever.
Such habits leads to better confidence when doing some plunging stabs: real space availability is known. So attacks can be unchained and enjoyment maximized.

Also watch out for internal damage. Reckless reactions can be hard on the joints and tendons. Better warm-up your upper body by playing a session of Audioshield, Soundboxing or whatever you like.

33438623.review:
This game is great. It is so much fun and it goes to show you how much a really good mechanic can drive a game, and provide many hours of fun. However I do have one gripe with the game so far.

The "story" mode is quite good right up until you defeat the last boss (at the time of this writing). After the last boss the main event starts to feel too long. The game starts you out in an arena with one naked dude to fight fisticuffs style. And as you get more kills with certain weapons you'll unlock more weapons to play with. That is great, and I love it. But after you fight the final boss (btw, we totally need the ability to re-play bosses, they are some of the most fun fights in the game) suddenly you're fighting crowds of 30+ fully armed and armored men. Just when you think you're done more enemies come out, and even though the mechanics are great, eventually you're going to take a hit no matter how good you are. And that leads to some frustration as weapon unlock requirements only count once you've finished an arena wave. Which means that the 10 minutes you spent killing through 30+ dudes only to have a door open behind your back and get sucker punched to death is all for waste. 

If I had to make a suggestion it would be to up the requirements to unlock weapons (ex. instead of 10 sword kills to unlock the bow make it 25), but make the kills count even if you fail a match. I believe that would take a lot of the frustraton out of the end-game. Plus weapon unlocks are a little too easy anyway, it feels like they are given away like candy. There is nothing wrong with having to work for rewards a little.

But despite that one gripe, the game is incredible, and I can't wait to see where the devs take it!

33436940.review:
While I did not pay for my copy (playing since closed beta) I wanted to support this game and the dev team so I bought 5 copies to give to friends.

This game is easily the most entertainment I have gotten from VR to date. There are other games I would consider a must-buy but this is the first early-access game I can recommend without hesitation. It's good enough that if development stopped (like some other EA games you may know) it would still be a worthwhile purchase. 

Watch some "let's play" videos on it and that should be enough to let you decide what you want to do, but my whole-hearted recommendation is to get it now.

33436925.review: #1 Best VR game to date. Seriously this game is an instant classic.

33436823.review:
Like many, i am a long-time follower of this pearl. 
GORN is the first game that made me think it was worth it to own an HTC Vive.
The only game that i spent countless hours (counting alpha version playtime which is not shown under this review) and that i showcase to all my friends and guests.
And it's being costantly improved.
The huge quality gap between any other VR game available right now makes it hard not being hyperbolic and euphoric about it. A must-have.

PROS
+Solid and satisfying melee combat
+Wide weapon selection, costantly expanding
+Distinctive graphic style
+Professional dev. Raithza is certain to keep its promises and chose to develop the game side by side with us players. You can be sure you're not wasting your money on an early access failure project.

CONS
-Enemies can be predictable. This will probably be fixed with the addiction of other Champions (boss) and by giving gladiators other weapons (i.e. two-handed)
-The difficulty curve is mainly regulated by gradually adding armor pieces to enemies and spawning more enemies, which dilute battle time without really focusing on making it more fun.

33434420.review:
[H1]Ever wanted to feel like a gladiator?[/H1]

Well, now you can with the murderfest GORN.
Gorn is a bloody and physically intensive gladiator-style arena VR fighter, giving you a wide variety of weapons (Swords, spears, axes, the mangled corpses of your fallen foes, your bare and bloodied fists) to slay a constant stream of randomly generated (As in, what weapons and armor) dopey-looking and 'highly trained' gladiators.

33434051.review: Just amazing! Now it's my favorite vr fighting game.

33434008.review:
Been playing this game for a long time since it was out on itch.io.  This is probably my favorite VR game and my go to when I put the HMD on.  I've been playing it for free but I'm not checking the box because I play to pay money for the game in some regard.  That's how much I appreciate the game.  The physics are on point, the challenge has been upped well in the later game.  Endless mode is a wonderful exercise (make it past a hundred kills to get a good sweat going) and loads of fun!  I enjoy unlocking the weapons every time I've reset my progress.  The limb dismemberment is amazing...I'm gushing, let me get to pro's and con's

Pros

-Great weapons with lots of variety.
-Immersive physics with great tricks to fool your brain into thinking you're swinging real weapons.
-The gore is fabulous, as long as your not squeamish. [Smashed noses with eyes hanging out made me kill the guy extra fast :)]
-Humor is well done, the crowd is fun.
-Active developers
-Fun way to exercise.  I'm gonna go buy wrist weights
-Replayability because the gameplay is just fun.
-There's more but my brain isn't working right now, just buy it for goodness sake

Cons

-With tons of limbs getting blown off, and armor physics and enemies, sometimes framerate drops to where it's annoying and the physics act funny.
-The weapon wabble affects my swing to where weapons like the ax and sword twist causing mis-hits.
-[This is half con and half compliment] The game is so fun, immersive and exciting that if you get too far immersed, you can easily swing outside of your play area, which cost me a controller :(.  I corrected this by having a physical object in my play space and tried to keep a foot touching it so I couldn't reach out of my space.

Get this game, you'll appreciate it.  I've played 14 hours as of this review.  I'm confident enough to say that number will go up.

33433614.review:
This is hands down the best VR game on the market (finally). I've played the free demo for hours upon hours, it's the most fun I've had in VR. I've only played an hour of this current build, but it's many times better than the demo and I know it's a game I'm going to play a massive amount of.

Months later: As of writing this I've put nearly 60 hours into this version of Gorn; the game is still a blast if a bit repetative. The developers are nice and constantly updating the experimental version of the game, their dedication is truly inspiring and model to what VR early access should be. The game is not perfect by any means; it's ridiculously easy and nausiating for many people. Gorn's lack of a teleport function is truly dissapointing as I seriously have fallen in love and want everyone to be able to play the game at it's best; when you're running around the arena beating the ever violent crap out of some brutes. Though the lack of a teleport function leaves a aserious majority of players from not being able to play very much if at all. Other than that; the game doesn't run amazingly well at times. Making custom games where you're slaughtering left and right, frame by frame movies where the main chracter can't attack for shit.

On the upside, this still has the best melee combat in a vr game, it's not realistic but I never felt like i was wacking at an object until it fell down. Some may complain that the game is just another VR game where you can just flail around. While this is true; part of VR is role-playing in the world you're set in. All in all; I love Gorn; though it seriously splits its player-base through meh locomotion. If you're running a barebones VR rig; be prepared to deal with lag at high body counts.

33432716.review:
First of all- I've been playing this game for the last 3-4 months or so, when the creator was offering his super-alpha build. The core gameplay is unchanged, but that's about the only thing that didn't have to be, while everything else has improved drastically.

The graphics are much more polished and help with the atmosphere. The battle damage on your opponents is clearer. The system of unlocks is now based on battles won plus some fairly easy to achieve requirements. And the new enemy spawn system helps with the flow of a fight- originally you took on everyone at once on the field, up to 8 gladiators in some cases. Now they come at you piece meal though mostly in more threatening groups- a good balance between a viscious brawl and a lopsided beatdown.

The one warning I will give, aside from the violence warning that should be expected- listen to the 2x2m rule. Know where things are. The trailer isn't overly exaggerating- in my 1.5x2m space (which does work) I and my friends have bashed the every living crap out of the Vive controllers. My wall has noticible dents. My controllers have had to have the plastic case popped back into place. They still work, mind. But in advising anyone who wants this game- it's worth it, but not $200 replacement controller worth. Or whatever a controller replacement goes for. I doubt the warranty covers that type of damage.

33431578.review:
I've been playing this game since its infancy, and even got the honor of participating in the closed beta. This game is absolutely nuts.

GORN is a combination of glory, gore, hilarity, and good fun. With a wide variety of weapons, it is possible to unleash your inner warrior/psychopath in numerous ways.

The developer is extremely responsive, so any bug you report gets squished very quickly.

The game has a regular, endless, and champion mode. While the champion mode (i.e. boss battles with unique gladiators) is a bit limited, the Arena and Endless modes are guaranteed to bring hours of fun.

The game itself involves a lot of physical activity, so a lot of sweating will happen. It is easy to whack something in real life by accident.

Overall, this game is a somewhat simple yet overwhelmingly entertaining experience. Buying it full price is worth it!

I wouldn't recommend this as a demo/introductory to VR game to family or friends. Had one damaged controller, lots of wall/furniture hits and a few near misses due to people not experienced with the chaperone boundaries. 
However don't let that stop you from purchasing this and enjoying it for yourself, it is seriously a bar raiser.

39183502.review:
[h1]And fight…[/h1]

[b]Disclaimer[/b]
I am a relatively new to VR plus I am not a violent person.
That makes it so surprising to me how much I enjoy this game even tough it is quite physically demanding.
 
[b]Overview[/b]
You will be a Gladiator in an Arena and you will compete against several other fighters and champions.

First you will start of with your bare fist with the goal to overcome your enemy, with time you will get new weapons which can cause quite gruesome injuries to your opponent but the goal remains the same.

[b]Rating[/b]
9/10 for regular Gamers
9/10 for Gamers not liking Gore (switch to optional mode)

[b]The highlights[/b]
[list]
[*] Great graphics
[*] Makes for a decent workout
[*] Challenging and rewarding
[/list]

[b]The lowlights[/b]
[list]
[*] Not all features implemented yes (Early Access title)
[/list]

[b]Motion Sickness[/b]
For those of you worrying about motion sickness the default way of movement is swinging your controllers while pressing a button.

Even though I am not that affected by motion sickness I did not experience issues with this way of moving around.

[b]Summary[/b]
I was looking forward to own this game since the reviews are full of praise and they are not wrong.
Be aware of your surroundings since you will get immersed quite easily and move around like a maniac hitting all kind of furniture outside your play-area if you do not keep track.

Never used my Vive Camera that much to make sure I am still in my area but this tells you how much this game sucks you in.

so i'm changing my review, so I think it's still a really fun game, i'd still recomend it.
it does however, have the issue that the game doesn't get harder as you progress, it just gets harder to enjoy progressing.
what i mean by that, when you get to like 30 rounds in or so, it'll start spawning horrific amounts of enemies, (like 30 or more in total) and all fully clad in armor and with shields, which on my system makes the framerate go to shit, but that aside, it makes it pretty much unplayable, because you have no where you can run, so you end up just grabbing onto the most OP weapon you can find (the war hammer) backing into a corner, and swinging around wildly hoping it'll glitch out and kill some dudes, so you'll be able to continue.
it'd be MUCH more fun if it spawned in a cap of about 8 or less enemies in the arena at once, and then gave them unique skills or armor (like the bosses have crazy abilities and armor, give the grunts some better armor, or skills) that way, as you learn new skills in playing the game, you get to apply them in really dodging, then swinging back, then running, etc, rather than what you have to do now which is cower in a corner from the 40 fucking dudes all fully clad in black armor, here to smother you with thier many flails.
TL/DR: it's a fun game but it needs a LOT of work with arena fighting, which is really what the game is made for, so i wouldn't recommend it unless it's on sale for at least 50% off, or untill they've made the arena fighting really more challenging and fun, rather than increasingly overbearing and annoying.

Definitely a keeper. I have a huge library, but this is now one of my top go-to's for party games and VR demo.

No complex story, but graphics are strong for the cartoon vibe, and the gameplay is surprisingly addictive and even the same army of bad guys plays out differently match to match. Good replayability.

Haven't played the game terribly long, but in the time I have thus far, I play match after match, slowly unlocking new weapons, that require different techniques, but come with hilariously bloody outcomes. Bad guys do come in variety, in terms of what weapons they use, and how much armor they have. After enough arena matches you get to do champion/boss fights in a sense. My last (and only thus far) was a guy in golden decked armor with a sword, and no known weaknesses. Was a good fight, ended up stabbing him through the face in what little exposed flesh his helmet afforded.

I could play this game quite a bit, and am getting quite a workout. 

I know my friends will appreciate this everytime they come over, and it will be fun to watch their shenanigans on the big screen (duplicated on the monitor).

Only wish they truly had a greater variety of bad guy skins, and perhaps different arenas. Also, it's a bit odd, that there's some voice acting involved, but mostly I never hear it, and only have the text to read. They should add a little more. 

Still, well worth the sales price I got it for ($15).

I usually get bored very easily when playing most VR games out there. This is not the case with this particular masterpiece of a slaughterhouse, though. The term I would use to describe this game is "disgustingly splendid".

But then if you were disgusted by dead bodies, I don't really get why you would be reading this right now.

Anyway, if you're like me and on the contrary love gorey games, this is the best you can find. Even after unlocking every weapon, bosses and gauntlets, it just keeps being fun. If you like fighting in VR, go for it. You won't regret it. At this price, it's basically a steal. It keeps getting updated too, with more weapons, bosses, content, and tweaks. 

9/10. Honestly the best I could find for the HTC Vive.

39562551.review:
[b] Played on GTX 1060 (6gb), HTC Vive [/b]

Watch our [url=https://youtu.be/HDg452GhpzA]Gameplay Demo [/url] or visit our  [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31780592-Underbyte-Gaming/]Curator Page[/url]!

[h1] TL;DR [/h1]

Imagine playing a game where you can hit an enemy so hard, it crashes your entire system. This is Gorn.

One of my favorite VR titles, it’s actually one the games that made me want to buy a HMD in the first place.  It might not be for everyone, especially for those who play VR to relax.  But if you’re looking to de-stress by participating in pure, unadulterated, mindless violence, and you have the play space required, you should definitely give it a try!

[h1] Warnings: [/h1] 

[b] Physically Demanding, Large Play Area Required, User Health Hazard, Innocent Bystander Health Hazard, Pet Hazard, Furniture & Electronics Hazard, Just be careful...[/b]

[h1] Audio/Visual/Performance: [/h1]

The art sort of reminds me of Borderlands without the comic-style black outline around the characters.  Enemies are big, muscle bound, ragdoll-like characters, and the spectators are giant floating heads that judge your every move from the stands above the arena.

As far as sound, the sound effects are great but everything else ultimately feels a little lacking.  The developers might have done it on purpose but there’s no music whatsoever, there’s also little variety when it comes to enemy taunts.  You’re basically beating your enemies to a pulp with your bare hands to the sound of spectators murmuring above you.  You honestly stop noticing as soon as you begin fighting but it would be nice to have a little background music.

The combat is physics-based (is that a thing?), meaning the harder you swing your arm, the harder you’ll hit your enemy.  I think that’s probably why this game works so well.  Yes, the weapons are rather wobbly, like they’re made out of rubber, but that’s the only way it would work in a game like this.  There’s a great feeling of satisfaction that comes from watching the enemy’s head fly across the map because you tore it clean off his body with one powerful swing.  As opposed to other games where it registers a “hit” and the death is animated.  These characters are ALWAYS governed by physics, you can see them struggling to even move, sometimes they may even trip over their own feet (which is hilarious).  It isn’t perfect however, sometimes you may hit an enemy in such a way that makes him glitch out and explode, sometimes resulting in a game crash.  But it’s so worth it.

[h1] Gameplay: [/h1]

Please, please, please make sure you have enough space around you and the play area is clear of obstacles (and people) before playing.  Do not let go of your controllers and make sure your Chaperone bounds are properly calibrated.  Otherwise, you may hurt yourself and/or others.

You begin the game in the lobby.  Here you can pick your game modes and change your settings (there are several locomotion settings for those who experience motion sickness).  You can also participate in trials and pick special weapons to fight with as you unlock them.

Once you step out into the arena, weapons will spawn in front of you and you can pick which one to start with.  There are lots of weapons you can use but there won't be many, if at all, on your first game.  As you complete challenges with certain weapons, you will unlock more and these will be randomly spawned every time you begin a new match.  Once you pick a weapon, you need to raise your arms to salute the emperor and begin.  The remaining weapons will disappear in a puff of smoke and the gate will be lowered.  If you wish to start off with more than one weapon, you may pick another with your off-hand.  Also, if you want to keep all of them just pick them up and drop them on the ground.  They will remain when the match starts and they’ll de-spawn over time.

You're a gladiator.  Your only task is to step into the arena and be the last one standing.  Once the gate is lowered you may begin slaughtering your enemies.  As you defeat them, more will come out of the gates around the arena.  Note that you can drop your weapons at any time and beat them with your fists or their own weapons.  You can even tear them apart limb from limb and beat their fellow comrades with their dismembered bodies.  If you pick a bow, spectators will periodically throw arrows into the arena that you can use in case you run out.

If you’re hit by an enemy, your sight will slowly fade out as your health depletes and eventually die.  However, if you kill an enemy before this, you'll gain a second wind regain consciousness.  Please note that while you may be able repeat this process multiple times, every time you’re hit your health will deplete faster and faster.

When the match is finished, spectators will throw coins at you and the emperor will ask you to salute him to end the game.  If you look directly under him, you'll notice a board that displays any challenges you made progress on or completed.  You may now salute him to return to the lobby and begin again to complete more challenges.

As you complete challenges you may unlock new weapons, as you unlock new weapons you unlock trials for that weapon.  You may also unlock new game modes and bosses that will in turn, unlock special weapons when defeated.

[h1] Game Modes: [/h1]

[b] Endless: [/b] Here you compete against endless waves of enemies.  You begin this mode with no weapons and must acquire them through combat.  Once you defeat 15 enemies in this mode, you will unlock Custom mode.

[b] Bosses: [/b] As you defeat bosses, you may unlock special weapons that you can enable to start the match with on Regular, Endless, and Custom mode.

[b] Weapon Trials: [/b] You can also participate in trials for specific weapons, you basically pick a weapon and see how many enemies you can defeat with that weapon.  You may access these in the lower levels as you unlock new weapons.

[b] Custom: [/b]  Once you defeat 15 enemies in Endless mode, you may take the elevator down to the lowest level to access this mode.  There are several settings you can experiment with like enemy or player size, enemy aggression, the amount of gore, a free-for-all mode, etc.

[h1] Multiplayer: [/h1]

Gorn features local multiplayer.  You can play with up to four players, with or against the VR player as a gladiator.  You may press start on any controller connected to to the computer while on Custom to activate multiplayer mode.  The controls take a bit to get used to but it’s great fun.  They also feature a “Party Mode” which I haven’t tested as of this time.

[h1] Final Thoughts: [/h1]

Let’s face it, this game does not need another positive review.  I think was a soaring success as a prototype on itch.io way before it released on steam.  But it’s one of my favorite games on VR so I think it’s only fair I give it proper review.  It honestly does not offer much in terms of story, but this game is amazingly fun, and engaging.  You’ll end up sweating buckets in mere minutes as you slaughter all your enemies,  I could not recommend it more.  Just make sure you have plenty of space around you, the original trailer does not lie.

[b] *This review is based on my personal experience with the game at its current state (date of review or last edit), and may be edited in the future as I play more and/or the game is updated.* [/b]

39529230.review: This is by far my favorite VR game, and might be my favorite melee combat game. It's a toss up between this and exanima, but if this game added a more exploratory style dungeon crawl campaign then GORN would be the obvious choice. I feel that the creators of GORN should fulfill their vision as they see fit, but I would love to see an RPG sequel to GORN.

39524497.review:
[h1] A bloody massacere and a good potential one at that [/h1]

[b] Story	[/b]

N/A  
Story - 0 out of 5

[b] Gameplay [/b]
There are a few elments I would like to focus on regarding gameplay so here we go!

[b] General goal of the game [/b] - You are in a battle royale between many other gladiators, simply eliminate them all in any gory manner you can think of and you win. Before starting the battle you must salute the emperor (holding your right arm up), I liked this, it's a nice touch to give you that VR feel, upon winning you must hold both hands up and cheer which is also a nice touch. After winning about 5 games you can face a champion, I can not remember how many there were but I do believe there are more upcoming in an update coming soon (surely?).


[b] Combat [/b] - Well this was....An experience, a bloody good one, no pun intended ofcourse. You can slice heads off, arms off, anything you wish you can even knock out their eye! Combat feels nice and the weaepons handle nicely but a lot more work needs doing on 2 handed weapons as they can be really awkward. Gore makes this game because it adds a whole repelayability feature on its own, I had a great time tearing heads off other gladiators like a true barbarian and I swear I am not crazy, (I am) but I love tearing people's hearts out with a spear (after swearing at the pain of using a 2 handed weapon!). I was'nt a great fan on the idea that you only have 1 hit until a small off screen timer starts in which you will black out until you kill someone, failing to do so is game over.


[b] Movement [/b] - I just have to point out, do locomotion although the developers method of moving is creative it's highly inpractical and just does not feel natural.


[b] The games biggest let down [/b] - They did something that I really respect because few developers shy away from the feature of gore, but thats it unfortunatley gore makes this game, if it was just a bit of blood this game ewould be nothing, sadly I feel there could be more especially since I beat all the champions in almost a day, infinite mode just isn't enough to make you want to play regulary, maybe a co op mode or versus mode online could change this?

Gameplay - 2.5/5.

[b] Graphics [/b]

Smooth well optimised, you really don't feel the screen door effect it's sharp everywhere you look

Graphics - 4/5.

Price - £11

£11 is what I paid and my advice to you would be wait for a sale, the games great fun but after a while you may go back to it here and there.

Value for money - 2 out of 5

This is hard for me, I want to say yes I recommend this game but at the same time theres more work needed, hey Steam wheres that neutral button?! It is fun but they need to find a formula for replayability as I always say about games, nothing will ever be a perfect game, but a damn good one makes you come back for more. wonderfully optimised, GORE GORE GORE! I may of been a bit harsh in some senses because this game really has come a long way, just needs to keep heading in the right direction

Things I liked:
GOOOOORRRREEEEE
Optimisation
General feel of most weapons are spot on

Things I didn't like
Voice acting was just simply looked over
2 handed weapons
Lack of replayability
No achievments or cards?! 


Overall rating - 2.5/5 

Spoiler alert:  [spoiler] I don't think I have ever used the word gore so much, ever. [/spoiler]
